In my electorate of Ballarat I have heard too many stories of individuals not being able to access the support they need or not being able to get into the scheme at the time they need to. This is particularly a problem for those with complex needs, as they struggle to work through the NDIS system to access support suited to their unique situation. Others have for too long been stranded in limbo, unsure if or when they will be able to access these services. I'm very aware of the negative experiences that many within my electorate of Ballarat have had with the NDIS and I'm also very aware of some of the reasons why.

Firstly, as was identified by the Productivity Commission, there are not enough staff within the NDIA and not enough providers of the services that people with disabilities need. Too often I have heard of people not being able to access the service they deserve and need simply because not enough capacity has been put into the system. One of the main reasons for this lack of support and capacity, frankly, is that this government has imposed a cap on the number of staff employed by the NDIA. This cap, in operation for a number of years, has severely restricted the ability of people with a disability to get into the scheme and access the services that they need. At the same time, the capacity of the market to meet the changing needs created by the NDIS has to be called into question. It is now the government's role to step in with a strategy to address these flaws. Another flaw with the NDIS has been its IT problems, which are well documented throughout the media.

Many families in my community have waited their whole lives for the NDIS. They are desperately in need of the services. Its implementation is not going the way it should. People cannot afford to wait any longer. I urge the government to do everything it can to improve the rollout of the NDIS, not only in Ballarat but across the country.

subdebateinfo.title: Menzies Electorate: Christmas, Rubens, Mr Erik

p.span: Menzies Electorate: Christmas
Rubens, Mr Erik

Mr ANDREWS (Menzies) (16:27): As Christmas and the festive season are fast approaching, can I take this opportunity to acknowledge, thank and encourage the many volunteers and organisations in my electorate who do so much for the wellbeing of others, including Doncare, the Returned & Services League clubs, the Lions and Rotary clubs, the local parish churches, the synagogue, the mosque, the senior citizens club, the Manningham Interfaith Network, the various aged-care and health services, and of course all the services associated with the Manningham and Maroondah councils.

Can I also encourage residents to embrace the festive cheer and to help families doing it tough in Manningham and Maroondah at this time of the year. Hundreds of individuals and families give to children less fortunate by donating to Doncare's wishing trees each year. Donated gifts then form part of Doncare's pop-up Christmas shop and give families experiencing hardship the opportunity to choose toys for their children at Christmas. This year Doncare's wishing trees are located at Bulleen Plaza, Warrandyte Library, the North Blackburn Shopping Centre, Aquarena, Manningham City Council and the Doncaster Library at MC Square. Simply take a tag from the tree and donate a new toy for a child or a gift card for a teenager.

The 36th annual Manningham carols by candlelight will be held on 15 December at 6 pm at Ruffey Lake Park in Doncaster. To capture the magic of Christmas, the Manningham carols by candlelight will conclude with the ever popular spectacular fireworks display. There will be a number of food stalls on the night, including that of the Rotary Club of Manningham, which will be putting on a sausage sizzle for a gold coin donation to a good cause.

I also encourage residents to donate to a good cause by obtaining a Lions Christmas cake from the Donvale Lions Club. Proceeds from this project are donated to the local community for some great causes, including blindness prevention and vision improvement projects, medical research, the Lions Children's Mobility Foundation, the eye health program, hearing dogs, disaster relief, and aged care, drug awareness and youth programs.

Speaking of volunteers, I pay tribute to Erik Rubens, a stalwart of the local Manningham community, who passed away suddenly over the weekend. Erik migrated from the Netherlands in 1983, finally settling in Melbourne. He had a strong background in international trade, marketing and wine exports. He was active in the small business network as well as an organising committee member for the Manningham Business Excellence Awards. He has been mentoring small business owners and operators for years, in addition to owning the Travel Store in James Street, Templestowe. He had been a very active member of the Rotary Club of Templestowe since 2013 and held a number of positions over the years. I extend my condolences to Janene and his two daughters, Helena and Sarah.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Howarth ): If no member objects, constituency statements will continue for a total of 60 minutes.
Workplace Relations

Mr STEPHEN JONES (Whitlam) (16:30): I want to speak out in favour of the hundreds of thousands of workers who are struggling to make ends meet as we go into the Christmas period. I particularly want to give a shout-out to workers who rely on penalty rates, and make some particularly harsh comments about members who have come to this place and failed to represent their constituents. I want to talk about the member for Dawson, who's spoken a very big game on the issue of penalty rates but, when given the opportunity to speak up and vote in favour of the 14,000 workers impacted by penalty rates in his electorate, he has left them stranded. Over 7,900 retail workers and around 6,000 food and accommodation workers have been sold out by their MP. We have all been reading with interest the comments in the newspapers and the backgrounding that has been going on for journalists in this place over the last fortnight: 'I will cross the floor, I will step down and resign from the coalition if things don't go my way.' But, when given the opportunity to stand up for people in his electorate and have the courage of his convictions, he went missing. The member for Dawson is rightly condemned by everybody in this place for talking one way and walking the other.

Of course, this is not the first time the member for Dawson has done this. In fact, he has a history of talking one way and voting the other. We all remember last year when he introduced a private member's bill to protect the Australian flag. This is the very same man who is voting in favour of legislation in the House to have the Australian flag removed from Australian ships so that Australian workers can be replaced by foreign workers to man those ships. This man has absolutely no credibility when it comes to sticking up for the people of regional Queensland. He talks a very big game when he's up there in his electorate, but he acts like a complete lamb when it comes to standing up for the people of his electorate here in parliament.

We can expect over the next few weeks the member for Dawson to be looking for some distraction from the embarrassment that he has suffered over the last week, selling out his constituency when it comes to penalty rates, and selling them out on so many other issues. We know that the member for Dawson has had things to say about religions that he doesn't like. We have heard him speak out over the last month about the importance of freedom of religion and religious protections when it comes to the same-sex marriage bill. But the very same MP has stood in the House and made some pretty harsh criticisms of people who practise faiths and religions that he does not like. The people of regional Queensland want somebody to stand up and speak out for them, but they want somebody to come here to parliament and vote in exactly the same way.
McPherson Electorate: Stronger Communities Fund

Mrs ANDREWS (McPherson—Assistant Minister for Vocational Education and Skills) (16:33): One of the ways the Turnbull government supports local communities and community based organisations is through the Stronger Communities Fund. Over the last few weeks I've had the pleasure of contacting a number of organisations in my electorate of McPherson to let them know that they have been successful in their application for funding under that program. There are, of course, many organisations on the southern Gold Coast that make a difference, but I would like to acknowledge the following who received well-deserved Stronger Communities Fund grants: the Burleigh Heads Mowbray Park Surf Life Saving Club for a new flagpole; the Currumbin Beach Vikings Surf Life Saving Club to renovate their clubhouse; Coolangatta Country Women's Association for renovations and audiovisual equipment; the Palm Beach Cricket Club for new cricket nets; the Palm Beach-Currumbin AFL club to refurbish change rooms; the Lab to provide new technology for young people diagnosed with high-functioning autism; the Benevolent Society for a new support centre for young people and their families; the Sanctuary women and children's refuge to upgrade accessibility and security; Burleigh Heads Rotary Club to provide no-cost mobility scooters for those most in need; the Twin City Baseball Club for portable fencing; Fight 4 Youth to buy a new van; and Mudgeeraba Scouts to revitalise their den. I'm pleased to say that there are a couple more to be announced in the coming week. My sincere thanks go to my Stronger Communities committee members: Jeff Davis, John Forrester, Hilary Jacobs and Catherine Pevy-Trewartha. Thank you so much.

Last week I also had the pleasure of announcing on behalf of the government $1.325 million in funding for Arcadia College in my electorate through the Capital Grants Program. Arcadia College takes a different approach to learning, and it's certainly a very inclusive environment. Students learn in a team with their own team leader in their own studio. There are currently about 190 students at Arcadia, with growth projected to 300 in the near future. This means that Arcadia College needs to expand, so the Commonwealth grant of $1.325 million will go towards stage 1 of the construction of a new facility that includes three junior secondary studios, staff offices, administration and an outdoor recreation area. It was great to visit the school and make the funding announcement with Principal Jason Sessarago, who leads a team of educators who are exceptionally dedicated to their students. I can assure you they were all very excited by the news. Well done to them.

I would also like to tell the House about a very worthwhile charity in my electorate that I'm supporting through my Christmas appeal. It's called Baby Give Back. The organisation is run by a group of local mums who are supporting mothers and babies who need assistance most. I'd like to acknowledge the directors: Carly Fradgley, Kylie Gregson, Ainsley McLaren and Julie McBride. Good-quality, new items that can help struggling mothers can be dropped off at my electorate office to be delivered to the charity. (Time expired)

Mr GILES (Scullin) (16:36): The majority of my electorate of Scullin falls within the local government boundaries of Whittlesea. This community is undergoing enormous growth at the moment, and that leads to some particular challenges. In the extended parliamentary break that we enjoyed, I was able to attend a couple of significant presentations on the challenges facing the communities which I represent. The first was a presentation by Whittlesea Community Connections, a community advocacy and support organisation about which I've often spoken in this place. It is a body that does extraordinary work on behalf of the most disadvantaged members of the communities that make up Melbourne's north.

The presentation that Whittlesea Community Connections provided to me analysed the changing profile of residents in the city of Whittlesea to inform decision-making and to deepen our understanding of the emerging trends. Their report found that, while some residents were highly educated and well skilled, others had very low levels of education and low levels of literacy. There are few entry-level jobs available in the area and there is very limited employment support for refugees. This is particularly concerning in light of this community's location as a resettlement place for Syrian refugees. From a health perspective, there are very high levels of chronic pain, depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder and general poor health in the community. There are also high numbers of people with disabilities. Housing affordability is a challenge. Utilities affordability is particularly poor, notwithstanding the rhetoric of the minister in this government. There is a high financial burden on people seeking family reunions—a very common issue in a community with a large population of immigrants, such as the city of Whittlesea. There are obviously very significant waiting times for language centres. There is fear and uncertainty amongst many who are facing future settlement delays, and there are concerns about legal processes and support. There is also a very high need for early childhood support and assessment. There is a desperate need to appropriately support victims of family violence—something the state government has been very serious about, something federal Labor is serious about, but something the federal government needs to take further action on. This analysis highlighted high levels of disadvantage which are not being dealt with and provides a very important framework to address those levels of disadvantage. It was backed in by the City of Whittlesea Council, and I congratulate mayor Kris Pavlidis and deputy mayor Emilia Sterjova on their election to their offices—particularly Emilia, the youngest deputy mayor ever in Victoria.

The report also highlighted infrastructure failings, a key issue in an outer suburban electorate. This issue is particularly compounded by the government's failure to appropriately invest in Victorian infrastructure, investing only nine per cent of Commonwealth infrastructure spending in Victoria, despite enormous population growth.
Banking and Financial Services

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (16:39): For many years I've been concerned about the circumstances that surrounded the Commonwealth Bank's takeover of Bankwest. Despite the inquiries by two parliamentary committees and the report of Small Business Ombudsman Kate Carnell, the controversy surrounding these cases has not abated. While the Small Business Ombudsman and my parliamentary colleagues have been as thorough as they could be, they didn't have the powers of a royal commission, and neither did they have the forensic questioning ability of a royal commissioner and the associated silks. It's been my view for some time that these cases need to be properly adjudicated by a qualified person who'll be able to test the claims and counterclaims of the victims and bank executives. For some time I've been making representations to the Treasurer and other ministers about the need for an inquiry. Last week the government established a royal commission into misconduct in the banking, superannuation and financial services industry. I'm pleased that aggrieved customers will now have their voices heard and their claims tested by retired High Court Judge Ken Hayne.

Following the Commonwealth Bank's purchase of Bankwest during the global financial crisis, the Commonwealth Bank began revaluing the Bankwest commercial loan book. In many cases the value of commercial property on which loans had been made dropped dramatically. As the properties were worth less than they had been under the non-monetary default clauses in the loan agreements, the Commonwealth Bank was able to trigger the default of a business loan, even though in many cases the borrower had been meeting their regular repayments against that loan. Bankwest victims, as I understand it, do not dispute the Commonwealth Bank's right under the loan agreements to call in their loans. The central allegation of the Bankwest victims is that the Commonwealth Bank, in exercising their power under these agreements, acted in a way that might entitle the victims to the right to equitable relief for unconscionable conduct.

I have a number of prominent constituents who've been adversely affected by the conduct of the Commonwealth Bank and who began telling me their stories in the years leading up to my election to parliament. One of my constituents, Peter McNamee, began talking to me about these issues at a Liberal Party branch meeting one night several years ago. Peter has been a member of the Liberal Party and my constituency for most of his life, including 28 years as a branch president. Peter's an engineer and second-generation property developer who was bankrupted himself in the 1990s yet dusted himself off and rebuilt a successful business. I suggested that Peter develop a policy paper for the Menzies Research Centre's small business round table, which he did in 2012. Peter wasn't a Bankwest victim, but he's become a great advocate for those victims. No-one's worked harder to get a result for them than Peter. He's been to every parliamentary inquiry and to other inquiries, met regulators and bank executives, and made submissions and policy reform suggestions. He's consulted by both regulators and bank executives today, and he's been an advocate for the royal commission. This royal commission is a direct response to people like Peter McNamee, who's a hero to me and to the victims, who will now have their chance to have their day in court, as it were.
Sydney Electorate

Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney—Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (16:42): I'm so proud to stand up and talk for just a few moments about the great honour it is to represent my wonderful electorate of Sydney. It is an incredibly beautiful and an incredibly diverse electorate—from scenic spots like Mrs Macquarie's Chair, looking back over to the Botanic Gardens, the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House and Lord Howe Island, to suburbs that have high needs: Woolloomooloo, just a few moments walk from Mrs Macquarie's Chair, and Waterloo, Redfern, Surrey Hills and Darlinghurst and right across down south to Rosebery and Alexandria. It's a beautiful electorate, a diverse electorate, and it's a great honour to be able to represent the people of this growing city of Sydney.

It is a city that of course needs continued investment in public infrastructure—in education, health and transport. Instead, we've seen from the New South Wales government a reverse Midas touch, it seems. On everything they turn to in my electorate, they are doing the exact opposite of what the people of Sydney want—the $2.3 billion about to be spent on two unnecessary upgrades of stadia at Olympic Park and Allianz Stadium in Moore Park when instead we should be spending more money on public transport, health and education. We see the obsession with WestConnex, one of the worst traffic projects Sydney has ever seen, moving the traffic jams we now see on Western Sydney streets right into the centre of Sydney, instead of connecting Western Sydney with the port and the airport as the state government promised. They're just moving a traffic jam from one part of Sydney to another part of Sydney, as well as the sell-off of public housing in Millers Point, the terrible decision to move the Powerhouse Museum from Ultimo, perhaps to Parramatta, or perhaps not to reopen it at all.

I am very proud of my electorate despite these terrible decisions of the state government, and proud of the fact that my electorate voted 83.7 per cent 'yes' in the campaign for marriage equality. That's happened because of the terrific work of many organisations that I've already acknowledged in the chamber. But I want to make special mention of the 78ers, people who have been campaigning for equality for years. We will see, sadly, the retirement of Reverend Graham Long from Wayside Chapel at the end of next year. We've seen Elizabeth Morley hand over leadership of the Redfern Legal Centre to Joanna Shulman this year. Both of these people have made a fantastic contribution to our local community.

Happy 10th anniversary to Gamarada, a fantastic organisation that provides great services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men. It was wonderful to celebrate their 10th anniversary with them. Sadly, of course, we've lost a number of great local contributors this year, and I'm very sad to see a number of deaths of Labor Party members this year.
Banks Electorate: Community Groups

Mr COLEMAN (Banks) (16:46): On 23 November, I attended the Carlton South Public School annual showcase down at Rockdale Town Hall. It was a fantastic night full of colour and dance and song. Carlton South Public School is one of the largest schools in my electorate, with about 600 kids. They represented it in fantastic fashion on the evening. I'd like to congratulate Patricia Floudas, the early stage 1 classroom teacher, who coordinated and organised the event, and also Principal Darren Galea for his ongoing leadership. The Carlton South Public School is a very tight-knit community with a very active P&C. It's great that we have been able, through the Stronger Communities Program, to assist the P&C with an important project to provide improved shade cover for the kids. It's a great school. It was a great night. Congratulations to all concerned.

On 6 November, I attended the 2017 Tots to Teens 11th annual arts awards exhibition at the Bankstown Arts Centre gallery. The Bankstown Art Society was established way back in 1953 in somewhat less modern premises than it has today. The Bankstown Art Society, like a couple of similar societies in the St George part of my electorate, does a great job in creating a space in which local residents can learn about art—some people might be a little bit interested and some people might be very, very interested—and learn from professional and highly skilled artists. The great thing about the Tots to Teens exhibition is that it showcases and highlights the work of kids in our community. It was a terrific night. I would like to congratulate the president, Jim Kelly, and the secretary, Joyce Williams, for all their efforts, and also exhibition head Noela Fisher for all her work. I look forward to my next visit.

On 22 November, I visited Carss Park for the annual St George Zone of Playgroups Fun Day. We have got a wide range of playgroups in our area in Oatley, Mortdale and a range of other suburbs across the Banks electorate. The Oatley playgroup runs one of the very few toy libraries in New South Wales and does a fantastic job. The fun day, as the name suggests, had lots of great activities. There was a little fire engine that kids could ride on, there were different food and drink things you could buy and lots of local businesses supporting the event. I'd like to thank Annette Ruhotas Morgan, the coordinator of the St George Zone of Playgroups, who is a volunteer. She does an amazing amount of work for a volunteer, as do so many other people involved in the playgroups of St George. It is a great organisation and one I'm proud to support.
Turnbull Government
Ms O'TOOLE (Herbert) (16:49): Thank you, Deputy Speaker:
In the spirit of the year's end fast approaching,
I thought: let's do some Christmas Grinch roasting.
Because 'tis the time to ponder and reflect
On the Prime Minister and every aspect.
Every Townsvillian likes North Queensland a lot
Except for the Prime Minister, who obviously does not.
To any proud North Queenslander, this is thought to be treason
But the Prime Minister seems to hate us for no good reason.
Maybe it is because he's too uptight
Or simply because his head isn't screwed on right. And at every parliamentary sitting he continues to ignore Herbert's calls.
For him to stand in this place, he has some gall.
Because Townsville is still without a long-term water solution,
And the excuses coming from this government are the equivalent of noise pollution.
There's Senator Gold Card, who's standing up for his own parliamentary retirement fund
Whilst, on water, he's saying he's not quite sure what it was people wanted funded.
It seems the local news, the Townsville Bulletin, my speeches and the opposition leader's demands
Haven't been obvious enough for this senator to understand.
Although he thinks this job is about standing up for himself,
He really needs a reality check—and maybe give the position to someone else.
There's the backflipping member for Dawson, who's just the Prime Minister's lap dog,
Whose lies and backflips could now fill a catalogue.
At the end of the day, the Prime Minister doesn't care about the regional Queenslander's plight
For he is too busy dealing with his own party's internal fight.
Whilst they bicker, Townsville's unemployment under this government has almost doubled
And yet this fact does not seem to make the LNP troubled.
In my electorate there are people who have been without a job for years.
They're finding it difficult to pay a mortgage and for food, and it brings families to tears.
There are people choosing between medical visits and paying electricity bills
And pensioners cannot afford to pay for their pills.
The Turnbull government has made massive cuts to education and health,
All whilst trying to privatise Medicare with very little stealth.
And our NBN, what an absolute disaster that has been:
Just mess and turmoil, something under this government too often seen.
And the complete disregard of our first-nation people—I'm in absolute disgust.
It's not fair, it's not right, it's so unjust.
I stand here today to tell this government: you are not doing good enough
And you aren't delivering for the people who are doing it tough.
Unfortunately for Townsville, this LNP Grinch won't have a change of heart
Because we have a government that isn't all that smart.
But, Townsville, rest assured I will continue to fight
Until the Prime Minister makes things right.
I will fight for jobs, NBN, defence and water too,
And I will never give up, for that fact is true.
Because Townsville deserves better than the LNP and One Nation doing dirty deals together,
And throughout it all we have had to suffer their chaotic weather.
I will fight, argue and hold everyone in this place accountable
Until action is taken to get Townsville out of trouble.
Townsville will return to a vibrant, thriving place,
But it certainly won't happen under this Turnbull disgrace.
Brisbane Electorate: Act for Kids

Mr EVANS (Brisbane) (16:52): Last month I spent a day in Far North Queensland with Act for Kids, who run SafeKIDS, a safe-house program running in Aurukun, Napranum, Pormpuraaw and Kowanyama. I was privileged to see the very real difference that safe houses are making in communities like Aurukun, keeping children safe by offering emergency short-term and long-term accommodation in community for children who aren't able to live at home at that time. Act for Kids is a charity based in my electorate, in Brisbane. They offer the safe houses in partnership with the traditional owners and the Queensland government's Department of Communities, Child Safety and Disability Services.

The safe-house concept was formed in response to the challenges faced by many Indigenous children, and young people under child protection orders, being placed in care outside of their communities—sometimes a very long way away, making it impossible for them to maintain their family, community and cultural connections. The program provides safe and culturally appropriate home facilities for children up to 17 years of age, allowing them to remain with their communities and stay connected to their families, culture and country while their ongoing child protection needs are assessed and implemented.

On behalf of the whole Brisbane community, I want to record my thanks and appreciation to Act for Kids for its great efforts in helping make our country a better place. I want to thank all of the Act for Kids team, their staff and volunteers, all ably led by their CEO, Neil Carrington, for their hard work and passion for child safety. I really enjoyed being able to have frank and meaningful conversations with many of them about their success stories, the challenges they confront and the opportunities in front of us all. I also want to thank, in passing, tireless child safety advocate Kay McGrath for accompanying us on the visit and for her dedication to the cause over so many years.

Reflecting on what we saw and heard there, I want to give honourable members a sense of how these safe houses are truly making the community safer. Safety really is a necessary precondition for any community where we're trying to help people succeed and thrive. Sometimes as policymakers we surely fail to appreciate how many of the usual policy options can fall away in challenging or remote conditions. Without safety, we can't expect to have young people going to school, learning, working and growing as individuals.

The safe houses are now the biggest employers in some of these communities, where the only other employer is often the local retail store. Act for Kids itself has a predominantly Indigenous staff, and I witnessed huge respect across the communities for the safe houses and for what they represent: the children and the very future of those communities. Act for Kids deserves our support and greater awareness.
Macarthur Electorate: Infrastructure

Dr FREELANDER (Macarthur) (16:55): Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Howarth—and I'm no Les Murray! My electorate of Macarthur is the most rapidly growing electorate in New South Wales. Property prices have rapidly increased, and so have mortgages. The average household has 2.2 cars, and the majority of workers travel to work by motor vehicle, with each vehicle having one occupant. The population of the area is expected to double in the next 20 years.

The new aristocracy, or perhaps not so new, are those that own large parcels of land now available for subdivision. The New South Wales government has just announced over 40,000 new home lots for the area yet no new public transport infrastructure. The federal government is building the Western Sydney Airport without any real commitment to a rail link to Sydney. The New South Wales government reaps billions of dollars in stamp duty revenue from families moving to Macarthur, yet it does not provide adequate transport infrastructure, adequate health infrastructure and adequate public school infrastructure. Many people spend two to three hours travel time to and from work every day.

I've made a submission to the Greater Sydney Commission outlining the above, and I think they have the will to do better, but, with the present state and federal Liberal governments, we're getting a very poor response. We've relied on motor vehicles in south-western Sydney for decades, and it's only going to get worse. We already have very poor air quality, and we'll have air quality of the level of New Delhi, I think, in the next few years unless something's done to reduce our reliance on motor vehicles. Long travel times increase stresses on families, give less time with children and reduce productivity. There's no doubt about that, yet the federal and state Liberal Party governments are quite discriminatory in their attitude to infrastructure. They're providing lots of infrastructure in inner Sydney, in northern and north-west Sydney and in eastern Sydney, yet to south-western Sydney they're providing nothing. The people of south-western Sydney have been forsaken by the Prime Minister and the New South Wales Premier, who are happy to spend billions of dollars of state revenue on stadiums that are quite functional and don't need to be rebuilt and on doubling up the transport infrastructure in inner Sydney and in eastern Sydney yet give nothing to south-west Sydney.

It is a disgrace. It is discriminatory. It reflects very poorly on the will of the government to provide for and care for all its population. This idea of privileged existence with infrastructure has to end. South-west Sydney needs support, needs public transport infrastructure, needs hospital infrastructure and needs schooling infrastructure.

subdebateinfo.title: Page Electorate: St Carthage's Primary School, Page Electorate: Trinity Catholic College, KTM Junior Supercross Challenge

p.span: Page Electorate: St Carthage's Primary School
Page Electorate: Trinity Catholic College
KTM Junior Supercross Challenge

Mr HOGAN (Page) (16:58): A group of seven students from St Carthage's Primary School, a Catholic school in Lismore, travelled to Flinders University in Adelaide recently to represent New South Wales in the social science division of the Tournament of Minds. Competing against thousands of students from across Australia, New Zealand, Vietnam and Thailand, the St Carthage's students took out top honours, walking away as the Australasian Pacific champions in the primary school division after also winning the New South Wales regional competition. I'd like to congratulate Charlotte Gilliland, Henry Lawrence, Layla O'Reilly, Clare Young, Jack Furness, Hilde Andreasen and Neve Schweizer. I'd also like to thank the team's facilitator, Jenifer Thomson, and the principal of St Carthage's, Janelle Heffernan, and all the staff at St Carthage's for fostering academic excellence in their students.

Well done to the Trinity Catholic College year 10 commerce students who won the recent New South Wales Mock Mediation Competition. The winning team comprised Nick Ledwith, Zara Webb, Tahlia Brien, Zoe Wood, Emilie Hughes, Sage Stein, Tory Puglisi, Haley Laarhoven, Heidi Pearson-Roden, James Sanderson and Tayla O'Reilly. Emilie Hughes also won the Student Advocacy Prize for being the best advocate in the state. The teacher behind the team was Jo Morgan, who was very proud and said they had worked extremely hard, having given up three lunchtimes a week since February to practise. Well done, Jo. In order to make the grand final, the school had to compete in a series of round robins, progressing on to the quarter finals, the semi finals and then the grand final, which was held in Sydney, against St Patrick's College, Campbelltown. Well done to everyone involved.

The KTM Junior Supercross Challenge is a unique opportunity for children to experience the life of a professional supercross rider. Eight-year-old Zane Thompson from Corindi Beach was recently chosen as one of 20 lucky aspiring supercross riders to experience the thrill of racing in front of a packed-out crowd at the 2017 AUS-X Open. Participants ride bikes fitted with ready-to-race kits and are required to navigate the entire supercross track, which includes large and technical obstacles. Riders are chosen based on their riding ability and school report card. Competing at the Qudos Bank Arena, which had been filled with mounds of dirt to create jumps, burns and whoops, Zane won his race in front of a massive crowd of 20,000 supercross fans. Zane's parents, Michael and Stacey, will certainly have their hands full when the local motorcross season starts soon, with their two other boys, Nate, 10, and Levi, six, who are also keen motocross riders. I wish them all the very best.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Howarth ): The time for members' constituency statements has concluded.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017

p.span: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Mr HILL (Bruce) (17:01): The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017 is a sad and accurate reflection of the Turnbull government. It is weak, it is insufficient, it is largely ineffectual and it is too little too late. I want to set out my strongly-held personal view at the outset. Let's be very clear: Australia's global anti-money-laundering rules are appallingly, embarrassingly weak. We all—Liberal, Labor and everyone else in this parliament—need to lift our game. It's gone on for too long. Allegations that the Commonwealth Bank breached these laws on almost 54,000 occasions are bad enough. That raises serious concerns about the weakness of the current laws and shows how badly exposed Australia in fact is to highly sophisticated organised money-laundering syndicates that operate globally.

But the reality is far worse and the problems are much wider than the banking sector. Most Australians, I believe, would be shocked to know that Australia's laws don't even cover key sectors of the economy. The so-called gatekeepers—real estate agents, accountants and lawyers—are not covered at all. In fact, by global standards, we are now way behind good practice. Transparency International published their assessment of Australia in March this year. Australia failed in all 10 priority areas. We were ranked worst in the Anglosphere. The global regulator of money laundering, the Financial Action Task Force, published their most recent evaluation in 2015. It's shocking reading. Australian homes are a safe haven for dodgy money, with particular concerns about Chinese funds. Australia's regime is not compliant with six key international standards, and, embarrassingly, Australia was placed on a watchlist, given our ongoing failure to comply with terrorism financing and money-laundering reforms.

The government talks a big game on national security and crime. We heard it today in question time: tough on crime, tough on national security. But it's hot air, because in this area they're way behind what's needed and need to lift their game and do so quickly. Serious risks exist. This is not trivial stuff. This is not people stealing five bucks from a bank. It is terrorism financing, and it is facilitating serious criminals.

This bill is manifestly insufficient. It implements the first set of recommendations from a 2016 statutory review. At first glance you might think this is reasonable progress—first tranche, off we go!—but it's not. These issues have been hanging around unfixed for over a decade, and this bill does, at best, I would estimate, about five per cent of what is needed. It is 11 years since the Howard government introduced what they said was the first tranche of the legislation, back in 2006, and since then it has not been fixed. We have had our period in government, and I will talk about that later on. This is the fifth year that these guys have been in government. This is not good enough. We don't need more reviews; we need the government to lift their game and introduce comprehensive amendments to the legislation, which is currently riddled with loopholes and gaps and is too weak for the threats that we face.

As I said, the bill is fiddling around the edges and the biggest gap is still the lack of coverage for real estate agents, lawyers and accountants, which this bill doesn't even touch on. The most urgent issue—and I'll make some remarks on this—in my view, is real estate agents and it's less complex, in fact, than the others. Why do I say it is most urgent? International experience in the USA suggests this is a major area for money laundering and potentially counterterrorism financing. For over 10 years we have been warned that we have a similar problem in Australia and we've done nothing. The difference is the US are now at least doing something tangible about it. In August this year, the US government extended a pilot program to crack down on dodgy real estate deals after 30 per cent of high-end real estate deals checked out under the US Treasury program involved people targeted for potential money laundering and suspicious activity. The program was expanded to cover luxury real estate deals in the big US markets to stop real estate money laundering by overseas buyers. It's a scary warning of what may be going on in Australia, completely unseen. We have seen an enormous flow of funds and alarm bells have been rung by our regulator and academics for years.

The FIRB data is the best available of what's going on. It does slightly overstate things because it is based on approvals, not completions, but it is, as I said, the best available. To give you a sense of the scale, in 2015-16 $122 billion of foreign direct investment stock was approved in the real estate sector. That included about $50 billion of commercial and about $72 billion of residential. China was the top source country, with $31.9 billion in residential. Other top source countries included the USA, Singapore, the UAE, Canada and Hong Kong. AUSTRAC's 2015 strategic analysis brief, Moneylaundering through real estate, recognised that this was a well-established money-laundering method in Australia. I'm not making this stuff up. This has been sitting there. It's from the regulator to the government and they haven't acted. They also said that, compared to other methods, this could be:
… relatively uncomplicated, requiring little planning or expertise. Large sums of illicit funds can be concealed and integrated into the legitimate economy through real estate.

And the international regulator's 2015 report specifically identified China as one of the countries from which laundering through Australian real estate was suspected to take place. To be clear, the Chinese authorities cooperate with us extensively in cracking down on money laundering where it's identified. There's no question about that. The problem remains that our systems to pick up dodgy transactions are appallingly weak.

Of course, it is not just Chinese criminal money that's a worry. Media reports over years abound of stolen funds from Papua New Guinea's coffers being laundered in Australia—more than $200 million in 2014, including through real estate. There was a shocking Sydney Morning Herald article in 2015 outlining how Malaysian officials bid up the price of an apartment block by $4 million over the value and then had kickbacks and dodgy invoices. Yet, today, the fact remains that Australian properties can still be bought and sold willy-nilly without any due diligence on the parties. Firstly, there are no requirements for real estate agents or related professionals involved in real estate deals to submit suspicious transaction reports, even if they suspect illegal activity. Secondly, there are no requirements to disclose the identity of individuals or beneficial owners behind foreign companies purchasing property in our country. Thirdly, there are no effective controls then of the practice of criminals buying and selling properties in quick succession to confuse the audit trail. I'm not making that up, either. Successive AUSTRAC reports from 2007 onwards have highlighted exactly that practice—you buy something, you sell it, you buy it, you sell it, you buy it, you sell it and, before you know it, the audit trail has no idea who originally owned it. Also, it links with other illegal activities such as drugs.

There was a report on the SBS in recent times where the CEO of Chinese international property investments website juwai.com said that 70 per cent of their clients pay in cash. This poses clear risks given that money sent through a financial institution like a bank would be assessed and reportable under the counterterrorism or anti-money-laundering legislation. AUSTRAC's brief included two specific examples of the proceeds of corruption in China being traced to real estate assets in Australia. I have some small exposure to the integrity issues around the investment side of things through my previous work in the Public Service managing business and investment migration. Checks are done quite carefully and thoughtfully on people seeking visas here and, yet, you can just move money in and out in this way because it's simply not captured by the regime in the real estate sector.

It's important that we can identify and stop suspect and corrupt transactions, not only to comply with our international obligations but also, importantly, because of the inflationary impact on property prices in Australia from funds that are not being properly and commercially invested. To their credit, the Attorney-General's Department acknowledged this in its recent discussion paper, on page 6:

Australia is likely to be an attractive destination for the investment of foreign proceeds of crime in real estate … [This] allows criminals to conceal and enjoy the profits from their crimes, but also can lead to the artificial inflation of property prices, as the criminal may be willing to pay more than the fair market value to secure a safe investment which minimises the chance of detection.

Residents in my electorate are extremely concerned about the impact of foreign investment on residential property values—for example, in Glen Waverley, which is a hotspot of concern within Melbourne. And I continue to get reports, almost every week and certainly every month, of dodgy transactions that are not properly regulated or caught, and the government has to act. A discussion paper with no commitment to implementation and no time line is simply not good enough.

The second point I'd make is in regard to disrupting terrorist networks. Extending the regime to cover the gatekeepers is also critically important to ensure that we can stop terrorists and their support networks. The December 2016 report published by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute was titled Detect, disrupt and deny: optimising Australia's counterterrorism financing system. It includes two case studies of concluded terrorism financing convictions in Australia in relation to al-Qaeda and the Tamil Tigers. Importantly—and this is important—the No. 1 recommendation for improving Australia's counterterrorism regime is: what do you think it was, Member for Brand?
Ms Madeleine King interjecting—

Mr HILL: Well, let me tell you: it was to regulate the gatekeeper professions—lawyers, conveyancers, accountants, high-value goods dealers, real estate agents, and trust and company services providers—under this legislation, to reduce the potential for misuse of those professions by terrorism financiers—
Ms Madeleine King interjecting—

Mr HILL: It's catchy, I know—and ensure that Australia's anti-money-laundering regime and counterterrorism financing regime is consistent with global standards. Money is the lifeblood of terrorist organisations. Who knew? It's necessary for obtaining weapons, mounting attacks, sustaining members and facilitating recruitment and propaganda. Detecting, disrupting, and denying terrorist financing is a powerful means of countering the terrorist threats posed to international peace and security.

So, this is not trivial stuff. The government needs to commit unequivocally to fixing this within the next few months. And the signs are not great. Worryingly, the Minister for Justice—he of the sparkling personality, one of the government's two secret weapons that they deploy to us in question time, to bore us to death; he's neck and neck for the gold medal with the Minister for Urban Infrastructure in the 'Boring Olympics'—stated in July:
We do have very robust arrangements in Australia, including for property …

Seriously: 'robust'! Robust, Member for Dawson. I'd hate to see what he thinks are lax arrangements, then, if he considers our arrangements to be 'robust'. The real estate lobby are hostile or lukewarm—quelle surprise!—about the need to even do anything. The REIA are sort of a bit cleverer: they kind of don't oppose it, but they seek a light-touch approach. Okay. The REIA Queensland, from the member for Dawson's neck of the woods, of course opposes this outright and says that these serious risks should just be dealt with by continuing professional development and awareness training—send them a memo; send them a fax. Give me a break. 'Trust me; I'm a real estate agent.'

I'm gravely concerned that the government will continue to go slow or quietly cave. The status quo cannot be allowed to prevail. The minister must come in here when summing up this debate and state unequivocally that the government will extend the regime to real estate agents in a meaningful way within six months. Enough is enough. The Attorney-General should stop measuring the curtains at Australia House in London and get this fixed before he leaves. The cost-benefit regulatory analysis was to be completed by mid-June 2017. I haven't heard anything about that. Anything short of a time-bound commitment is weasel words and should be called out by all members, the media and the public. And I say this to my party, because we have been in government and not dealt with this: we need to stand firm and be very clear, unambiguously, that if the government fails to act then we in government will—no weasel words. Time doesn't permit a detailed account and comments in relation to the need to extend the regime to accountants and lawyers. Suffice it to say that that case is also strong and coverage is well overdue.

Once we've dealt with real estate agents, accountants should be the next cab off the rank, and there are pretty well-thought-out models around. Submissions to the statutory review from the various professional bodies—I got a bit nerdy and read some of them—including the CPA, proposed a two- to three-year transition period with some broadly sensible caveats. I acknowledge also the particular issues in relation to the legal profession—it is more complex—and think the Law Council of Australia's submission does provide a way forward. Whilst the Law Council strongly opposes, in principle, the extension of the regime to lawyers—'trust us, we're lawyers'—it goes on to signal a sensible way forward if it is so extended, which is always the bit you have to read. There are things like excluding legally privileged information—fair enough—and making arrangements for barristers so they don't drown that profession in red tape and can rely on the arrangements put in place by law firms.

In closing, enough is enough. This has gone on for too long. The laws were introduced in 2006. They were the first of an anticipated two tranches of legislation to bring Australia into line with international best practice. Eleven years ago, it was expected the second phase would follow soon after, but 11 years on we're still waiting. At the tail end of the Howard government—most of that government was its tail end—in 2007, they flagged that consultation would progress on the form of the second tranche. There was even draft legislation—it's kind of out there—10 or 11 years ago. The Rudd government continued work and did have industry roundtables but put the reforms on hold for a few years, given the impact of the GFC on business, which made sense at the time. But that time has passed and there is no excuse, no reasonable explanation, for the ongoing delay.

This government started their review in 2013—that's four years ago. You're in your fifth year, government, and all we have is another review, another half-done first tranche, which doesn't even pick up on all that it was supposed to. I will use my last half a minute to point out that this bill pretends to implement the first tranche but mysteriously misses many recommendations, with no explanation. Recommendation 4.8, about digital currency wallets, is just not there, along with recommendations 14.1 and 14.2 about secrecy and access amendments, and at least five others. It remains entirely unclear whether a decision has been taken to not proceed with those reforms or whether they're in the never-never. In conclusion, I take this matter seriously and I think the government should do, too.

Mr KHALIL (Wills) (17:17): I'm pleased to contribute to the debate on the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017. We know that Australia has experienced some sustained pressure from many stakeholders across the globe to strengthen our anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing regime. This has been consistent over the past decade. In the course of this debate I think it's safe to say that both sides of the parliament understand that this piece of legislation is well overdue for an update. The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 is the principal legislative instrument to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. It establishes reporting regimes for prescribed entities and provides procedures which reporting entities must go through to properly identify customers before engaging in transactions, including international and domestic fund transfers.

As the member for Hotham, the shadow justice minister, noted in her remarks, taking the profit motive out of crime is one of the key elements to maintaining law and order. Therefore our anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing legislation is immensely important within this objective. There's an urgent need for reform and it's well demonstrated in the scandal involving the Commonwealth Bank, in which AUSTRAC had initiated civil penalty proceedings in the Federal Court against the Commonwealth Bank of Australia for serious and systemic noncompliance with the existing Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006.

This bill implements a first phase of reforms arising from the recommendations of the report on the statutory review of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 and the associated rules and regulations. I won't go through all of the details of the bill—we all know them. What I do want to say is, although it is acknowledged that this bill implements only the first phase of the necessary reforms, it's important that all aspects of the bill are as strong and as robust as possible. While Labor are supportive of this bill on the basis of an initial review, we are concerned that the bill may not go far enough, particularly in light of the recent scandals that I have just referred to, including that involving the Commonwealth Bank and many others.

The 2015-16 report of the Financial Action Task Force, part of the global body responsible for setting and monitoring international standards on combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism, found that Australia's regime for anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing was noncompliant with at least six international anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing standards. This report called on the regulator, AUSTRAC, to pursue a more aggressive enforcement agenda, recommending:
Australia should focus more on effective supervision and enforcement of individual reporting entities' compliance with AML/CTF—
anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing—

obligations within the various sectors. Here's the kicker: the double standard, the smoke and mirrors show on display by this government. It spruiks its record on national security with photo opportunities in front of tanks—everyone wearing helmets and maybe some fatigues, with a few guns in the background. It talks almost obsessively from one side of its mouth about cracking down on organised crime and terrorism, while from the other side it refuses to invest in law enforcement or commit to meaningful regulation and oversight of the banks.

Here are some facts: the very same year in which that criticism of our financial intelligence agency was made by the global organisation the Financial Action Task Force, AUSTRAC actually sustained a $7 million cut from the Abbott Liberal government's 2014-15 budget. So, while Australia was being told to ramp up its anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing efforts and enforcement, the Liberal government cut eight per cent of AUSTRAC's budget. The government is cutting funding to AUSTRAC—the body that is supposed to be monitoring these institutions and enforcing our laws. I note that the 2016-17 budget contains a $19 million cut to AUSTRAC's work to protect the financial system from criminal abuse.

We've seen, of course, in recent days that the government have rolled over and decided to hold a royal commission into the banking and financial sector. Despite resisting Labor's calls until the eleventh hour, they are now talking big on how they plan to clean up misconduct in the banks. Despite all of this—despite the smoke and mirrors by this government—Labor, in particular the member for Hotham, the shadow minister for justice, and the member for Isaacs, the shadow Attorney-General, are willing and eager to work with the government over the coming months on the more significant challenges Australia faces in responding to money laundering and terrorism financing. It's very clear that Labor's not going to stand in the way of legislation that strengthens our anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing regime. To be clear, this is an issue with direct bearing on our national security, and we don't do smoke and mirrors; we do the real, substantive stuff, the real work that's necessary.

It must be said that the ripping of millions upon millions of dollars out of AUSTRAC at the same time as professing to strengthen it through this particular legislation is just another example of the con job of this government. Despite that, I call on the government to work with Labor to ensure we deliver robust legislation which will underpin the safety and security of all Australians.

Mr THISTLETHWAITE (Kingsford Smith) (17:22): This bill amends the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006. The bill implements the first phase of reforms arising from recommendations of the Report on the statutory review of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 and associated rules and regulations. That report was tabled in the parliament on 29 April 2016.

The AML/CTF Act provides the basis for regulation of certain businesses by the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre, AUSTRAC. The regulatory framework established under the AML/CTF Act and the FTR Act provides for the collection of information from the private sector, and from inbound and outbound travellers, about the movement of money and other assets. AUSTRAC shares this information with associated financial intelligence and designated agencies, non-designated Commonwealth agencies and AUSTRAC's international counterparts in order to combat money laundering, terrorism financing and other serious crimes. This bill aims to strengthen some of those provisions that exist in Australia at the moment, specifically by expanding the objects of the AML/CTF Act to reflect the domestic objectives of such regulation, to bring digital currency exchange providers into the regime, to provide regulatory relief for industry, to strengthen AUSTRAC's investigation and enforcement powers, and to give police and customs officers broader powers to search and seize physical currency and bearer negotiable instruments and establish civil penalties for failing to comply with questioning and search powers. The proposals also revise the definitions of 'investigating officer', 'signatory' and 'stored value card', and they expand the rule-making powers of the AUSTRAC CEO across a number of areas.

The importance of a strong AML/CTF regime in counterterrorism financing cannot be overstated. Money laundering and terrorism financing are relentless threats. The criminal networks that lie beneath impact on all levels of society, from the state to the individual. The Paradise Papers recently have shown how easily money can be moved and held overseas in opaque corporate structures away from regulatory scrutiny. These methods can be utilised readily by criminals seeking to clean their cash, finance terrorism or prop up corrupt regimes.

Earlier this year, the country was rocked by money-laundering allegations and actions that were aimed at the Commonwealth Bank after AUSTRAC alleged, in August, that the bank had failed to properly report more than 53,000 large cash transactions through its intelligent deposit machines between 2012 and 2015. Basically, these machines allow people to deposit up to 200 notes at a time, and often they are able to do that multiple times, onto a key card or a particular card from which an individual can't be identified. The actions that have been taken by AUSTRAC are unprecedented, and the alleged nature of the breaches of any money-laundering laws really highlights the necessity for a banking royal commission and also for the strengthening of associated laws in banking.

Despite this, the government has been attempting to avoid a royal commission into the banks for some months now in Australia. They've been eager to ensure that proper scrutiny wasn't entered into in terms of bank behaviour, particularly in some of the big four banks and the scandals and rip-offs that we've seen there. For the last 600 days, the Prime Minister has been saying: 'No, we won't be having a royal commission. There's no need for one.' He's been ignoring the pleas of the victims of the banks, the whistleblowers and the people who've said that we need a royal commission in this country, including many members of parliament and senators, particularly those senators who were involved in the initial Commonwealth Bank inquiry into wealth management scandals who recommended, on a bipartisan basis through a Senate committee report, that there should be a royal commission in this country. The Prime Minister denied that. Yet, when the big four banks write to the Prime Minister and say, 'We want a royal commission,' the Prime Minister rolls over and gives them exactly that. This, of course, came not from the realisation of the extent of some of the shonky actions and the rotten culture of the big banks but from a request from the banks themselves. If ever there has been any evidence that the government was acting in the interests of the banks, this backflip is it.

The anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing regime is long overdue for an update. In 2015, the Financial Action Task Force, the global body responsible for setting and monitoring international standards on combatting money laundering and the financing of terrorism, found that Australia's AML/CTF regime was non-compliant with six international AML/CTF standards. The FATF called on our regulator, AUSTRAC, to pursue a more aggressive enforcement agenda, recommending that Australia should focus more on effective supervision and enforcement of individual reporting entities and compliance with AML/CTF obligations within various sectors.

In the same year that these recommendations were made, AUSTRAC sustained a $7 million budget cut. It was the Abbott Liberal government that has been cutting funding for AUSTRAC over the forward estimates. AUSTRAC sustained a $7 million budget cut under the Abbott government's 2014-15 budget. When Australia was being told to ramp up our AML/CTF enforcement, the Liberal government had cut eight per cent of AUSTRAC's budget. Breaches of our AML/CTF regime are an issue of international and national security and we can't afford to take that threat lightly. In this time of heightened anxiety and international alarm, and being aware of and on notice about terrorism incidents, we need to ensure that the regulators, principally those bodies that are working to uncover terrorism financing and money laundering, are adequately resourced to do their job.

Unfortunately, yet again this government is cutting funding for AUSTRAC. The 2016-17 budget contains a $19 million cut to AUSTRAC's work protecting the financial system from criminal abuse. As I said, in the context of what's going on internationally this defies belief. It absolutely defies belief that as a nation we face increased threats from global terrorism and sophisticated criminal syndicates seeking to move their ill-gotten gains around the globe for nefarious purposes, and yet this government is cutting resources from the regulatory bodies that are charged with tracking down this behaviour and protecting our country.

In conclusion, Labor does support this bill and the elements that will strengthen the AML/CTF regime, particularly giving the AUSTRAC CEO the power to issue infringement notices for a greater range of regulatory offences and allowing the CEO to issue remedial direction to a reporting entity to retrospectively comply with an obligation that has been breached, and giving police and Customs officers broader powers to search and seize. The bill will also bring digital currency exchange providers such as Bitcoin into the AML/CTF regime. However, the government has taken a particularly light touch approach to this reform. Under the government's proposal, digital currency exchange providers would only need to report transactions on physical currency of $10,000 or more. This is despite the fact that their own consultation paper on digital currencies proposed that a threshold of zero dollars apply to digital currency exchange providers and disclosure. So it's a lighter touch than would otherwise be the case. Nonetheless, Labor do support this bill because we recognise the need for strong laws in this space and the increased threat posed by ever-advancing criminal syndicates, and I commend the bill to the Federation Chamber.
Debate interrupted.
PARLIAMENTARY REPRESENTATION
Qualifications of Members
Mr FEENEY (Batman) (17:32): Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Hogan ): Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
Mr FEENEY: No, I do not. I seek to make an explanation of a personal nature.
The DEPUTY SPEAKER: The member may proceed.

Mr FEENEY: I thank the chamber. I rise to make a statement in relation to citizenship. In 2007, I was nominated for election to the Senate as a candidate for the Australian Labor Party. As a part of my nomination process I completed a form entitled 'Checklist for eligibility', which asked if my parents or grandparents were citizens of another country. This vetting process was compulsory for all Labor candidates. As a result of this check, I was advised by the ALP national secretariat that, as my father was born in Northern Ireland, I should renounce my citizenship entitlements under British law. I was also advised that out of an abundance of caution I should also renounce any entitlements under Irish law. I can advise the House that neither I nor my father, nor any other member of my family, is or has been an Irish citizen, nor have any of them taken any steps to enliven any entitlements to Irish citizenship.

In October 2007, I signed the documents prepared for me in accordance with the advice, renouncing my rights and any other rights to which I might have been entitle, and I understood that they had been sent to the British and Irish governments. As a part of the universal disclosure process, I contacted the British high commission regarding the declaration of renunciation I made in October 2007 to request a copy of that notice. In subsequent correspondence, the high commission informed me that they were having difficulty locating this information. They had checked with the UK Home Office, which deals with these kinds of queries, and they stated that they do not keep records for such long periods of time—from which I understand they could not locate my notice of renunciation.

In order to establish that this form was indeed submitted in 2007, I have inquiries outstanding with the UK Home Office to confirm, firstly, whether my original documents, such as my notice of renunciation from October 2007, would have been destroyed, whether addressed to the Home Office or the high commission; and whether there are any other historical or archival searches which may be made to locate my declaration of renunciation. I have also sought past bank records from more than 10 years ago to determine whether I made a payment processed by the UK Home Office at the time.

To the best of my memory from a decade ago, I followed the advice I received and sent renunciations to both UK and Irish authorities. It, of course, makes no logical sense that I would do one and not the other. However, I accept that I have been unable to produce the requisite notice of renunciation with respect to the United Kingdom. I remain hopeful that continuing searches of UK records in archives will clarify this matter in my favour. Nonetheless, I accept that at this moment my status as a citizen in UK law remains unclear. On this basis, if the relevant documents have not been located by the time this issue is dealt with in the House of Representatives, I will be asking the Manager of Opposition Business to refer this matter to the High Court. I thank the House.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017

p.span: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Dr ALY (Cowan) (17:34): I rise to speak on the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017. As speakers before me have stated, this is the first phase of reforms from the recommendation of the Report on the statutory review of the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006 and associated rules and regulations. As speakers before me have also stated, Labor broadly support the proposed bill. Our anti-money-laundering and counter-terrorism-financing regime is long overdue for an update. Too often we are left playing catch-up with terrorists and organised crime groups instead of being ahead of the curve and focusing on what we can do in prevention and early intervention as opposed to disruption.

Way back in 2015, the Financial Action Task Force, or FATF, which is the global body responsible for setting and monitoring international standards in this space, declared that Australia's regime was noncompliant with six international standards. Broadly, the task force recommended that Australia should focus more on effective supervision and enforcement of individual reporting entities' compliance with the AML/CTF obligations within various sectors and not just the financial sector. The importance of this cannot be underestimated or overemphasised. As I said, we cannot continue to play catch-up with terrorists and criminals, who continue to find ways to fund their destructive activities under the watch of this government.

At the same time as the task force was making these recommendations, the Abbott Liberal government ripped $7 million from AUSTRAC in the 2014-15 budget. This government likes to talk big on how tough it is on crime and national security. What could be more important to our national security than cutting off the flow of finances to terrorist groups? Terrorists and organised criminals rely on these funds. They rely on them to set up training camps, to develop their influence propaganda, to recruit would-be terrorists and to finance transnational and domestic terror attacks.

Supporters of Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, or Daesh, and other jihadist and terrorist organisations are actively looking to and promoting the use of new and emerging technologies such as bitcoin to mitigate some of the risks associated with traditional fund transfer methods. Indeed, some websites associated with terrorist organisations have started to collect donations in bitcoin. It's not rocket science to understand how attractive it is for terrorists and criminals to use cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin for financing, because they offer anonymity, they have global reach, and they're fast, final, cheap, easy to use and difficult to track.

These are things we've known for years, and yet this government has sat on its hands and done nothing about it. So exactly how tough are you on national security when you refuse to acknowledge this, you refuse to do anything about it and then, to top it off, you rip money out of the regime that is responsible for enforcement? The recent charges by AUSTRAC against the Commonwealth Bank around alleged breaches of money laundering and antiterrorism laws are extremely serious and, indeed, deeply concerning. So why will this government not ensure that financial institutions and companies are doing the right thing in not allowing their facilities to be used to fund crime?
Here I refer to recommendations 10, 11, 12 and 13 of the FATF report that explicitly relate to customer due diligence and record keeping. Recommendation 10, for example, states:
Financial institutions should be prohibited from keeping anonymous accounts or accounts in … fictitious names.

In the Commonwealth Bank case, we saw the bank allegedly accepting cash deposits through intelligent deposit machines, followed by international and domestic transfers. The bank is alleged to have failed to report cash transactions totalling $624.7 million made through these machines to AUSTRAC in time for assessment, thereby failing to comply with the requirements of AUSTRAC and failing to assess the risk of money laundering or terrorism financing. Yet this government, in its 2016-17 budget, cut $19 million from AUSTRAC, again impacting negatively on AUSTRAC's ability to do the kind of work that is necessary to protect the financial system from criminal abuse.

This government has been dragged, kicking and screaming, like a two-year-old having a tantrum, to finally calling for a royal commission into the banking and financial sector. And make no mistake: this is not a show of the Prime Minister's strength or concern about the criminal abuse of the financial system. This was not prompted by a concern for the victims of unscrupulous dealings by the banking sector. It was not a sudden change in the Prime Minister's consciousness or an epiphany of compassion and care that caused him to backflip so spectacularly on a banking royal commission. No. This was prompted by one thing and one thing only: the Prime Minister's desperate attempt to keep his job. He has time and time again opposed a royal commission and, only now, when the big four banks have said, 'Oh, okay; I guess you should do it,' decided that, 'Hey, maybe Labor have been right on this all along.' I hope that the process will be a fair and transparent one that delivers for the victims of the banking sector. But, to be honest, I'm not holding my breath.

This government beats its chest and talks big on cracking down on organised crime and terrorism. There's hardly a day goes by in question time when the Minister for Justice or the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection do not stand up and crow about how tough they are. But the proof of the pudding is in the eating, to use an appropriately festive phrase. Despite all their chest beating and crowing, they've failed. They've failed to invest in law enforcement and failed to commit to any meaningful regulation and oversight of the financial system and the non-financial sector to ensure that it's not abused by criminals.

And they've failed to recognise and respond to the gaps in our capabilities and capacity to really deal with trends in terrorist financing. Our law enforcement agencies do not have the capacity to deal with terrorist immigration to the dark web and the use of cryptocurrencies for financing their activities. I have yet to hear one person from the government—including the Minister for Justice, who just doesn't seem to get any of this—speak about this issue or even recognise it as an issue. We have a Minister for Justice who simply doesn't have the capability to do his job in this space. He's like a deer in the headlights. He doesn't understand the area and he takes little interest in what legislative changes are needed to effectively act on terrorist financing and what capacity building we need to ensure that our agencies are well equipped to keep ahead of trends.
Recommendations 15 and 30 of the FATF report speak specifically to this. Recommendation 15 states:

Countries and financial institutions should identify and assess the money laundering or terrorist financing risks that may arise in relation to (a) the development of new products and … the use of new or developing technologies …
Recommendation 30 states:

Countries should ensure that designated law enforcement authorities have responsibility for money laundering and terrorist financing investigations … ensure that competent authorities have responsibility for expeditiously identifying, tracing and initiating actions to freeze and seize property …
Recommendation 31 states:
Countries should ensure that competent authorities conducting investigations are able to use a wide range of investigative techniques …

Then we have a minister for immigration who stands up and screams about national security and puffs out his chest to look like the tough guy, but has absolutely no idea what his own government is doing to undermine the ability of Australia's regime to comply with international standards in anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing by ripping money from AUSTRAC. You couldn't get a more ineffective pair of ministers when it comes to actually doing something about national security and counterterrorism: ineffective, inexperienced, unknowledgeable and utterly clueless.

While this bill goes some way to addressing some of the concerns in the FATF report, it falls short of addressing all of them. It will be effective in expanding the objects of the AML/CTF act, bringing digital currency exchange providers such as bitcoin into the AML/CTF regime, giving the CEO of AUSTRAC the power to issue infringement notices for a greater range of regulatory offences, allowing the CEO of AUSTRAC to issue a remedial direction to a reporting entity to retrospectively comply with an obligation that has been breached, and giving the police and Customs broader powers of search and seizure for AML/CTF breaches. But it will not completely address all of recommendation 4 in relation to the Vienna and Palermo conventions and the Terrorist Financing Convention. Importantly, it doesn't cover non-financial businesses and professions including casinos, real estate agents, dealers in precious metals, lawyers and notaries, and trust and company service providers—all of which are mentioned under recommendations 22 and 23 of the FATF report.

Australia is a top destination for money laundering. That's primarily due to our lax rules around accountants, lawyers and real estate agents. We simply can't allow this to continue. Yes, we have a bill that goes some way to addressing the lax standards in our regime. But simultaneously ripping out money from AUSTRAC while only addressing part of the recommendations made by the FATF report way back in 2015 will not completely address the issue at hand. We need to be able to look at where our gaps in capability are and fill in those gaps, whether it's through a legislative instrument or whether it is providing more resources and better resources to our law enforcement agencies, and to the regime to enable it to do its job in stopping money laundering and the financing of terrorist activities.

In closing, while Labor supports this legislation in so far as it strengthens our anti-money-laundering and CT financing regime, we will be carefully examining the details to ensure that this piece of legislation is sufficiently robust to address the current gaps in that regime. Like the speakers before me, I too reach out to the government to say: Labor is willing to work with you on this.
