This can only be achieved by a bipartisan approach in which we collectively look at what those gaps are, use our expertise on both sides to identify those gaps and fill those gaps through a more robust legislative framework.

As the member for Kingsford Smith and the member for Cowan have rehearsed, there are many issues associated with the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017 that are of concern in relation to the general government approach to security. Labor works very assiduously in attempting to have a bipartisan approach to security matters and we wouldn't normally air issues about these things in public. But we're greatly disturbed by what is transpiring in the House in relation to the shameless politicisation of security—particularly the references to China, which are extraordinary when you consider the hypocrisy and irony of that. Consider, for example, that the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister were wined and dined by Chinese communications company Huawei in China and both came back vigorously advocating for that company's participation in the NBN, regardless of and despite the fact that our security agencies strongly recommended against that. I'm well aware of the detail of that advice.

Andrew Robb, former member and former minister, presided over a FIRB process that allowed the sale of the port of Darwin, a significant strategic asset, to the Chinese, a cause of great consternation to the Americans. They let us know that in no uncertain terms. The lack of consultation over that, as a minimum, was a significant issue in the relationship, because we both use that as a military asset as well. You can add to that the sale of Ausgrid in New South Wales, where Ausgrid managed significant defence infrastructure, and Treasury in the FIRB process did not consult at all with Defence over that sale. Defence had to raise the red flag, so to speak, in that process. When we were in government, Labor endeavoured to set up and manage our own data centres, but then the new government, wanting to save money, looked at leasing data centres, one of which, Global Switch, was handling much sensitive material and was subsequently the subject of a Chinese takeover, raising alarm bells again.

In relation to this legislation, as my colleagues have detailed, AUSTRAC features prominently in what we seek to deliver in tackling terrorism financing. The attacks on AUSTRAC's budget are of great concern, as are the delays which we've seen as this matter is dealt with. The legislation of 2006 provided for a seven-year review of the operation, which is as it should be, because we see a lot of evolutionary trends in this area. It's a daily challenge to keep track of the morphing of financial movements and technological developments, as the member for Cowan highlighted, particularly in relation to cryptographically based digital currencies like bitcoin, which is not covered in the current arrangements under the act. That seven-year review commenced in December of 2013, and the minister didn't table the report until 29 April 2016. That was three years, so there was not a great deal of urgency in the processing of that. This legislation is also supposedly dealing with phase 1. I'll come back in a moment to what our government did in relation to terrorism financing, and the deficiencies of this government on that very serious matter, but we hope that, in the next phases of this legislative process, many of these issues that aren't addressed in this legislation are picked up, because they are necessary.

The recent revelation of upwards of 55,000 breaches of the anti-money-laundering and counter-terrorism-financing legislation, just in relation to one bank, one financial institution, is deeply concerning. The royal commission that has been announced into the banks must include terms of reference that deal with that issue if this government wants to be serious about his credentials on counter-terrorism-financing, otherwise their treatment of terrorism-financing will be a complete joke and farce. That must happen.

I'll briefly canvas some of the issues out there at the moment relating to terrorism financing. We've seen a lot of commentary about the threat of North Korea. North Korea is not just a threat in relation to its ballistic and nuclear missiles; North Korea sustains its efforts in this sphere, and does end runs around sanctions regimes, largely by being a regime of criminal transactions. The nation is effectively a mafia fiefdom. The Strategic Studies Institute includes narcotic trafficking and counterfeiting of United States currency in that activity, as well as many other issues, such as blackmail arms sales, the sales of its nuclear know-how—we know well its connections with Iran on that matter; I'll come back to that in a moment—and the sales of scud and other missiles to Hezbollah, Iran and Syria.

These are all important issues, but North Korea is focused on cryptocurrencies at the moment. There is a whole military enterprise set up to steal cryptocurrencies. They have an office called Office 39, which is a bureau that's dedicated largely to engaging in illicit economic activities. Every cog of the nation's machinery is mobilised to facilitate the regime's racketeering. Defectors have often described how there are schoolchildren working in poppy fields to help with the narcotics trade. Cash and smuggled goods are brought in on state owned merchant vessels. There was an issue that I was involved in where we were tracking a North Korean vessel off Australia's shores in this respect. This is a direct threat to us, a direct interest to us and a global and international issue. So we need a great deal of focus in relation to this legislation on how we tackle the crime bosses of North Korea. This is as important as any other measure that we take, particularly noting that it is defeating sanctions regimes.

We have a great deal to learn in this respect from what Task Force Harpoon delivered in Israel's situation. They were obviously confronted with a significant threat from terrorism financing and went down this road very early in the piece. There were waves of suicide bombings in the late nineties and early 2000s. What was revealed in their detailed examination of terrorism financing was how it required so much money. Setting up suicide bombing regimes involves purchasing safe houses and vehicles, investing in the ability to construct suicide vests and explosive devices, and then there's an entire pensions regime to pay off the families of the suicide victims. So an entire regime was developed around these things. What transpired was massive amounts of money—hundreds of millions of dollars—being poured by Iran into Hezbollah and Hamas, associated too with Hezbollah's global criminal activities, it also being involved in narcotics dealings with Mexican syndicates and in Venezuela, and with money-laundering activities in West Africa. Hezbollah's global financial reach is just astronomical. Israel engaged in an extremely aggressive approach to dealing with that counter-terrorism financing. As I've often said privately in a lot of meetings, we could deal with terrorism through battalions of accountants as much as we deal with it through battalions of infantry and other kinetic operations.

That global picture of counter-terrorism financing is a very significant one. As we know, Iran is significant in that regard. Just recently, one of the global organisations that really focuses on this issue highlighted that Iran was actually in the top three of nations in the world for money laundering and counterterrorism financing. This is why I am disturbed somewhat by the government's approach to dealings with Iran. Earlier we heard a question posed about what the Labor government was doing in this space. Labor, when in government, not only rigorously applied the United Nations sanctions in relation to Iran but also introduced legislation on autonomous sanctions regimes. Under that legislation, we enabled Australia to engage in many levels of activity beyond what was contemplated in UN sanctions. In March of 2012, we produced a guidance note for advice to businesses and others that detailed what those countermeasures would entail in our autonomous sanctions and UN sanctions regimes, specifically in application to Iran. Special attention was given to business relationships and transactions with Iran, including Iranian companies and financial institutions, and countermeasures were applied to protect financial sectors from money laundering and terrorism-financing risks emanating from Iran. We put out a lot of warnings and engaged directly with businesses to make sure that they were aware of the details of the issues and risks and threats that were presented by the way that Iran conducted its business. This was an extensive financial operation.

As we've seen in the legislation and the reports on where this needs to go, in relation to how correspondent banks deal with the transactions associated with financial distribution and flow of activity around the world, those banks are obviously a key means by which actual currency transactions take place—the central one of those currencies, of course, being that of the United States, because so much of foreign currency revolves around the US currency.

And it was litigation operations established during that wave of suicide bombing that really helped bring to the surface the involvement of banks that involved themselves in arm's-length processes in this—the Arab Bank, the Lebanese Canadian Bank and others. AMEX was approached and dealt with in some legislation as a correspondent bank. So, a lot of progress was made in that litigation to highlight that problem and to also hold those institutions accountable and pay the financial penalty for being involved. Labor introduced that autonomous sanctions regime and fleshed that out with specific targeting of Iranian interests and activities.

What I'm disturbed about is that the current government has bent over backwards in recent times to really develop a relationship with Iran that is quite unhealthy. Of course, the world has been moving away from the UN-related sanctions on Iran in relation to its nuclear activity, but not completely. And of course the United States maintains quite a degree of sanctions that relate to Iranian activities in this field of terrorism support. So, it's a shame that the current government has moved away from those provisions and from the autonomous sanctions provisions that we had in place. This is really concerning when we see ministers like the trade minister planning to open an office in Tehran and encouraging Australian businesses to get involved there as an opportunity. In fact, a quote from him is:
There's a significant opportunity for Australian trade to Iran, now that the sanctions have been removed.

I'd encourage the government to take a closer, harder look at the way Iran operates as one of the top three nations in the world. It was highlighted by the Basel Anti-Money Laundering Index in 2016 as the highest money-laundering risk out of 149 countries surveyed by the Basel index.

So I think the government has dropped the ball in relation to Iran. Obviously I understand why this was the case. They were bending over backwards to try to win Iran's support for taking Iranian asylum seekers. And of course we saw the foreign minister over there trying to curry favour, trying to get them in the door to coalition meetings in relation to activities in Iraq, which was rejected by the other coalition partners. And it was all for nothing. There was absolutely no way Iran was ever going to take asylum seekers back from Australia in those circumstances, so they were really stringing the foreign minister along. The foreign minister was engaging in activities and allowing agency activities in relation to Iran that we shouldn't have been involved in. I won't say any more on that, but it's deeply disturbing, the degree to which the foreign minister was taking us down this road of this closer relationship with Iran and the way in which this government is watering down the counterterrorism financing legislative arrangements in relation to Iran.

I would encourage the government to re-examine this. Our own financial institutions have flagged that it is really difficult for them to actually work out how to work with Iran. For example, Cassandra Winzenried, senior economist at Efic, said:
Iran's external and fiscal situation makes it relatively non-risky but the payments experience has not been tested and there are some large problems with the banking system.

There is a problem that our institutions have with confidence in dealing with Iran in relation to those issues because of the relationship it has with terrorism financing in particular. I'd encourage the government to get off its political bandwagon on these issues of China and actually focus on practical measures to fix the terrorism threat that this nation faces.

Mr KEENAN (Stirling—Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Counter-Terrorism) (18:03): I thank all honourable members who have contributed to the debate regarding the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017, which will strengthen protections against Australian businesses being misused for money laundering or the financing of terrorism. The bill will update Australia's AML/CTF regime to close a regulatory gap that has arisen with the emergence of digital currencies. Digital currencies are growing in popularity in Australia as a method of payments for goods and services and transferring value in the Australian economy, yet to date they have operated largely outside the regulated financial system. In doing so, the bill will also reinforce legitimate use of digital currencies.

The government is also pleased to be able to provide industry with some regulatory relief by simplifying and streamlining regulatory requirements. The bill deregulates two sectors, recognising the lower money-laundering and terrorism financing risks associated with them. Deregulating cash-in-transit operators will provide savings of approximately $326 million over the next 10 years, and deregulating some insurance intermediaries and general insurance providers will provide savings of over $500,000 over the same period.

The bill also improves and streamlines the operation of the correspondent banking provisions under the AML/CTF Act and better aligns with current international banking practice. The bill also enhances the ability of related corporate bodies to share information within corporate groups about the money laundering and terrorism risks associated with shared customers. This change will better reflect the way businesses actually structure themselves.

The cross-border movement of physical currency and bearer negotiable instruments, such as traveller's cheques, is a known money-laundering and terrorism financing method. The bill contains enhanced search and seizure powers for police and Customs officers that will strengthen their ability to enforce reporting obligations and to take appropriate action where there is suspicion of money laundering and terrorism financing. The introduction of civil penalties for some offences related to the cross-border movement of physical currency and bearer negotiable instruments will provide law enforcement with greater flexibility to respond in a proportionate manner to these offences.

The number of amendments in the bill will strengthen the important role of AUSTRAC as Australia's anti-money-laundering and counterterrorism financing regulator and financial intelligence unit. The bill will update the powers and functions of the AUSTRAC CEO to better reflect and support the full range of work performed by AUSTRAC. These changes recognise the growing role for AUSTRAC in supporting international efforts to combat and disrupt money laundering, terrorism financing and other serious crimes. Introducing the power for the AUSTRAC CEO to issue remedial directions to require regulated businesses to retrospectively rectify contraventions of a civil penalty provision will help address financial intelligence gaps created by a failure to report.

The bill will also strengthen the AUSTRAC CEO's powers to supervise the registration of remitters to assist in addressing the higher risk posed by this sector. The new power to cancel the registration of a person who is no longer conducting remittance activities will ensure that dormant registration certificates are not used by third parties to avoid AUSTRAC scrutiny. Infringement notices under the AML/CTF Act provide a flexible and responsive option to encourage greater compliance with the act, reducing costs for both businesses and AUSTRAC. The bill extends the use of an infringement notice beyond the current six regulatory offences to an additional 11 minor regulatory offences. The bill will also make a number of additional amendments to the AML/CTF Act. The AUSTRAC CEO will only grant exemptions that could have an effect on money-laundering or terrorism financing risk where such a risk is low. The bill also expands the objects of the AML/CTF Act to reflect the domestic objectives of the legislation.

I note that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee tabled its report on the provisions of this bill on 16 October. The committee recommended that the government consider clarifying certain definitions in the bill through amendments either to the bill or to the explanatory memorandum. The government has carefully considered the findings in the committee report. The government amendments to this bill clarify the definition of stored value cards and the treatment of certain betting instruments under the AML/CTF Act. These amendments will ensure that betting products such as slips and vouchers are captured under the AML/CTF regime but not as stored value cards. This is consistent with the treatment of gaming chips and tokens under the AML/CTF Act.

The committee's recommendation also asked the government to consider whether the terms 'article' and 'in the course of carrying on a business' should be clarified. While the government appreciates that these matters are complex and that some submitters raised issues of uncertainty, the government does not consider that additional amendments to this bill are necessary. Further amendments may have the unintended consequence of introducing additional uncertainty for stakeholders that could result in inconsistency with existing provisions of the AML/CTF Act. The bill has been drafted to provide flexibility and to future-proof the act. I'd like to thank the committee for its work in considering this bill. The committee's report recognises that submitters were generally positive about the provisions of the bill and that the bill would bring about an improvement in the operation of the AML/CTF Act.

This bill is the first phase of what will be comprehensive reforms to Australia's AML/CTF Act to make sure that the regulatory framework that we have established remains effective against the evolving threats of money laundering, the financing of terrorism and other serious financial offences. Legislation is only part of the answer, and efforts to protect Australia's financial system from serious crime require the support of the private sector. The government will continue to work closely with all affected industry sectors to ensure that this bill and Australia's AML/CTF regime continue to effectively achieve that goal.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Consideration in Detail
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

Mr KEENAN (Stirling—Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Counter-Terrorism) (18:10): I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill, and I ask leave of the Federation Chamber to move government amendments (1) to (3) as circulated together.
Leave granted.
Mr KEENAN: I move government amendments (1) to (3) as circulated together:

span.span: (1) Schedule 1, item 79, page 34 (line 4), omit subparagraph (ii) of the definition of
stored value card
, substitute:
(ii) a gaming chip or token, or a betting instrument; or
[betting instruments]
(2) Schedule 1, page 35 (before line 4), before item 80, insert:
79A Section 5
Insert:
betting instrument
means a thing (whether real or virtual):
(a) that represents monetary value or digital currency value; and
(b) that is designed to be used for the purpose of, or for purposes which include:
(i) placing or making a bet; or
(ii) paying out winnings in respect of a bet;
but does not include:
(c) a gaming chip or token; or
(d) a thing that, under the AML/CTF Rules, is taken not to be a betting instrument.
[betting instruments]
(3) Schedule 1, page 35, after proposed item 79A, insert:
79B Subsection 6(4) (table item 7)
After "gaming chips or tokens,", insert "or betting instruments,".
79C Subsection 6(4) (table item 8)
After "gaming chips or tokens" (wherever occurring), insert ", or betting instruments,".
[betting instruments]

p.span: As I've just foreshadowed in my summing-up speech, these amendments give effect to the recommendation of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee, and I thank them again for their report in relation to this bill. The committee recommended that the government consider whether the terms 'stored value card', 'article' and 'in the course of carrying on a business' could be clarified with a view to addressing some uncertainty expressed by some submitters to the inquiry. Following further consultations with stakeholders, the government determined that there is some uncertainty in relation to the proposed definition of 'stored value card' in the bill—specifically, whether certain types of betting vouchers are captured. For the purposes of clarity and certainty, government amendments have been prepared that rectify this issue. The bill will be amended to provide a definition of 'betting instrument' which includes betting vouchers; amend the designated services in table 3 in section 6 of the AML/CTF Act to explicitly capture betting instruments; and exclude betting instruments from the definition of 'stored value card'. These amendments will ensure that betting instruments such as slips and vouchers are regulated under Australia's AML/CTF regime but not as stored value cards. This is consistent with the treatment of gaming chips and tokens under the regime. The government does not consider that additional amendments are necessary. Further amendments may unintentionally introduce additional uncertainty and could result in inconsistency with the existing provisions of the AML/CTF Act. The bill has been drafted to provide flexibility and to futureproof the act.

Ms O'NEIL (Hotham) (18:13): I rise to speak briefly on the amendments that have been proposed for the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Amendment Bill 2017, which concern the definition of 'stored value cards'. Stored value cards such as gift cards and travel cards are increasingly being used by criminals to launder money and finance terrorism. These cards have been used by cybercriminals to defraud Australians, by foreign fighters to fund terrorist activities abroad, and even by terrorists to finance aspects of the Paris attacks that occurred in November 2015. This year AUSTRAC released its first risk assessment of stored value cards, and in that document it warned:
… the hardening of the banking and remittance sectors against criminal misuse … may increase the risk that SVCs will be used for terrorism financing.
So I'm pleased that there's been an amendment to the bill that looks at some of these areas.

I am concerned, though, at the minister's attempt to link this to the committee's report, because anyone who has read the committee's report would see that, although it noted some issues around stored value cards, the amendments that are being proposed in the Chamber right now have nothing to do with that recommendation. The Law Council Australia made a submission to the Senate inquiry asking that the bill provide greater clarity regarding stored value cards issued by financial institutions. That's not the amendment that is being moved by the government. We are happy to consider this amendment, but, like the bill more broadly, it frankly only tinkers with the edges on what is a very important and significant challenge which faces our country in our fight against terrorism. The amendment and this bill will not have a significant impact on Australia's ongoing issues with money laundering or terrorism financing. Like much of what we see from the government in this space, it makes a big noise about the things it is trying to do on terrorism but, when it comes to the policy and the legislation, they are just not up to the job.

I reiterate what I said in my second reading speech. Labor stands very willing and very eager to work with the government on what are very significant reforms that are acknowledged around the globe need to be made to the regime. This bill doesn't even come close to addressing those matters, and we are waiting for activity and leadership from this government.
Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House with amendments.
CONDOLENCES
Fife, Hon. Wallace Clyde 'Wal'
Consideration resumed of the motion:

That the House acknowledge the passing, on 16 November 2017, of the Honourable Wallace Clyde (Wal) Fife, a Member of this House for the Division of Farrer from 1975 to 1984 and Hume from 1984 to 1993, place on record our nation's gratitude for his service, and its profound sympathy to his family and friends and former colleagues.

Mr TAYLOR (Hume—Assistant Minister for Cities and Digital Transformation) (18:16): I'm grateful to be able to speak today on this condolence motion to honour Wal Fife, an enduringly successful former federal member for Hume who had a penchant for people and a knack for numbers. If Wal had written a book on grassroots politics, it would have been a bestseller. No doubt, an entire chapter would have been devoted to the art of village visits—advice he so kindly shared with me when I was a candidate, which I readily absorbed.

Wherever Wagga Wagga went, Wal went. In 1984 he squared off against prominent National Party member Stephen Lusher and a tough Labor candidate for the newly redistributed Hume, which had taken in Wagga. At that stage, Wal had previously been the member for Farrer. Wal was always a gentleman, a man of the people who had time for a yarn. His great friend and adviser and a former Yass Liberal Branch President, Dr Jonathan Williams, recounted to me that Wal's village visits probably swung that election in 1984 in Wal's favour. 'One has to look beyond the Cootamundra dinners,' Wal always used to say. He put that to great effect in 1984, turning up to Wee Jasper, a very small town just outside of Yass that I used to represent, a place Lusher hadn't visited for years. In a few moments, Wal had completely wooed 44 Wee Jasper locals, winning their hearts, minds and approval at the ballot box.

Wal was a statesman of consequence and a mentor of mentors. I like to think that there are many of us in the House today, including myself, benefitting greatly from his legacy. He was the major influence on my predecessor and mentor, the late Alby Schultz, who went on to become the longest serving member for Hume since Federation. 'Wal Fife is the reason I went into politics,' Alby said when he announced his retirement in 2012. 'He guided and nurtured me and is still giving me advice.' Alby, in the same way, guided and nurtured me as a candidate in my early days as the member for Hume. Very much in the Wal Fife mode, Alby would remind me where I came from, to be honest and to make time for people.

Dr Williams always says that Wal was an absolutely outstanding constituency MP. He would dictate to his secretary, Mrs Nugent, constituent replies, notes of personal thanks, birthday cards and vote-winning strategies for particular towns and villages while driving the car from one end of the electorate to the other, which would take, in those days, most of the day.

Alby Schultz's wife, Glo, who remains a very local and close friend, said to me of Wal: 'There was no-one else in politics who carried out their job with more respect for protocol. He was a statesman in every sense of the word.' When Alby contested the seat of Burrinjuck in 1988, Glo recalled Wal being always encouraging and guiding: 'But that didn't stop him from having a quiet word to me on occasion about protocol—about what I should say and what I shouldn't. He was strong on things like that but always warm and encouraging.' Glo says that Wal also used to have a saying—that politics is like a wheel, but the trick was to keep moving forward. He was always making progress in the right direction. Former Deputy PM Tim Fischer, the former member for Farrer, said that Wal had masterminded the establishment of Charles Sturt University. He had worked closely with Dr Cliff Blake, the then vice-chancellor of the Riverina-Murray Institute of Higher Education, to bring the multicampus university into existence. We all see the enormous benefit of that today.

Over a federal parliamentary career spanning 17 years, Wal would serve only the first 18 months on the backbench before his elevation to the Fraser ministry as the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. He would go on to serve as the Minister for Education from December 1979 to May 1982 and as the Minister for Aviation from May 1982 until the defeat of the government in 1983. He also served three stints as minister assisting the Prime Minister, twice in the area of federal affairs and then, from 1980 to 1983, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Public Service Matters. He would have marked 70 years as a member of the Liberal Party in January 2018, and 14 December will mark 60 years since he won the state seat of Wagga Wagga. He not only put his life into the Liberal Party; it was his life. Just hours before he died, he was told that he was to be made a life member of the Liberal Party in recognition of his service.

My thoughts and the electorate of Hume's thoughts are with his wife, Marcia; with their children, David, Allan, Carolyn and Susan; and with their 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. I offer my deepest condolences to them.

Mr McCORMACK
( Riverina — Minister for Small Business ) ( 18:22 ): I share the sentiments and eloquent words of the member for Hume about Wal Fife, a great friend of both of ours and a great friend of our regions. I stand here today sharing a unique bond with the late Wallace Clyde Fife. We are, and were, the only two Wagga Wagga born men to represent the city in the House of Representatives in the federal parliament. I can recall contesting a very robust three-cornered contest in 2010, in which the late Wal Fife, the late Alby Schultz and the late Joe Schipp were all very keen to see the Liberal candidate running for the seat of Riverina succeed.

I grew up in a household in which Wal Fife was revered—absolutely revered! My late father, Lance, and my mother, Eileen, thought Wal Fife was the best politician that could ever be hoped for. Indeed, he was. As the member for Hume just pointed out, he was a mentor to all of us. He was the reason that many of us embarked on a political career. Even Kay Hull, the former member for Riverina before me, remarked just what a mentor Wal Fife was for her. Of course, Kay and I are both National Party members and very proud of it. I appreciate the member for Hume is a Liberal, and, let me tell you, Wal Fife was a very, very proud Liberal, and so he should be!

After winning the seat, in 2010—as I said, it was a rather vigorous contest—it took me a little while to summon up the courage, but I thought I should go out and get anointed, as it were, by Wal Fife, because, as I say, he was a very special friend of my family. His farm, Gundary Pastoral Company, at Harefield near Wallacetown, was not far from Brampton, Brucedale, just nine miles out of Wagga, near Junee, on the Olympic Highway, where I grew up. And so it was that on 11 August 2011 I drove out to Gundary for morning tea with the Fifes. Marcia greeted me at the door and ushered me into the study, and there was Wal holding court with all the papers around him. He'd suffered a stroke some time prior to that but, I tell you what, he hadn't lost any of his wit or memory. Even though it had been a long time since he'd graced the frontbench of the House of Representatives, he went through each of the frontbench Liberal and National Party members one by one and absolutely summed them up, and, dare I say—for our Labor friends here—some of the Labor people too. He knew absolutely everything about the parliament. It was, of course, the hung parliament that we had between 2010 and 2013, and Wal knew everything about it. It was great that, over a cup of tea, a scone and a sandwich, he did anoint me and said he was very pleased. He knew my family, so he thought I'd be okay. From time to time I sought Wal's advice, and from time to time we would run into one another at functions. He was always very gracious, and I know that I had Wal's respect—as, of course, he had my lifelong respect.

There's another link between Mr Fife and me. After serving 18 months on the backbench after being elected to federal parliament in December 1975, Mr Fife was appointed Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, two ministries that I now hold portfolio responsibility for. I'm Australia's 17th Minister for Small Business since 1988 and I share Mr Fife's dedication and, indeed, his lifelong interest in protecting consumers.

Wal Fife, as the member for Hume pointed out, was born on 2 October 1929. He was the son of William Clyde Fife, an agricultural produce merchant, and Myrtle Elizabeth Wyatt. He was born into a family committed to public service. His father served as an alderman on Wagga Wagga city council, and upon his death Wal's older brother, Harold, was elected to council and went on to serve as deputy mayor—and a fine deputy mayor and historian he was, too. Harold Fife also served as president of the Wagga Wagga sub-branch of the Returned & Services League and was made a life member of that sub-branch. Harold died in 2011, aged 92.

Wal was educated at South Wagga Public School, Wagga Wagga Public School and Canberra Grammar School. He loved writing letters to politicians. In 1945 he wrote a letter to Winston Churchill after Churchill lost office. He said: 'I started off the letter by saying I was a 16-year-old Australian schoolboy, one of the many Australians who would like to thank him for his services during the war years. I made the point that it must have been a regret to him that, so close to the end of the struggle, the British people had cast him aside.' Churchill replied, thanking him for his kind message and saying he had read the letter with great pleasure.

In 1947, Wal wrote to opposition leader Robert Menzies seeking a position in the Liberal Party of Australia's federal secretariat. A year later he was appointed clerk and received a congratulatory letter from Menzies. He didn't stay long in that role. In 1949 he joined the family business, Fifes Produce, but he did not stay idle in public life. He was active in the Wagga Wagga and Albury political scenes. Wal wrote in his book, Wal Fife: a country Liberal—required reading, I think, for every federal parliamentarian: 'In the late 1940s the Liberal Party was still only a fledgling organisation and it was quite unusual for a person my age living in the country to join it. Furthermore, my father was vice-president'—here you go, Member for Hume, you're going to love this—'of the Wagga Wagga branch of the then Country Party.' So Wal had a little bit of Country Party/National Party blood in his veins. He said: 'Everyone, including the president, expected I would join the Country Party. Instead, I joined the Liberals, and I joined it for very good reasons.' He talks about the leadership that was required to form a strong government. He said that he felt it was a party for all Australians, regardless of whether they lived in the city or the country. I know that was espoused by the late great Alby Schultz as well. Mind you, he had great things to say about my friend the member for Hume here, and certainly I know the member for Hume is following in Alby's footsteps as far as being a great Liberal Party member.

Wal goes on to say, 'In 1948, I joined the Liberal Party and in doing so changed the course of political history in Wagga Wagga.' Indeed he did. He served as member for Wagga Wagga in the New South Wales parliament from 14 December 1957 to 15 October 1975—17 years, 10 months and two days. Quite remarkable service. He served as Assistant Minister for Education, Minister for Mines, Minister for Conservation, Minister for Power, Assistant Treasurer, Acting Minister for Transport as well as Minister for Highways. When appointed Minister for Education in 1965 he was 35, and at the time he was the youngest minister ever appointed in New South Wales. He resigned as member for Wagga on 15 October 1975 to contest the federal election in the seat of Farrer. He was elected to federal parliament on 13 December 1975. It was a red-letter day for the federal parliament. He served on the backbench for 18 months before being appointed Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Fraser ministry. He went on to serve as Minister for Education.
Debate interrupted.
GRIEVANCE DEBATE
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That grievances be noted.
Drugs: Diane-35

Mr HILL (Bruce) (18:31): Nearly a year ago a 64-centimetre blood clot almost killed my healthy 20-year-old daughter, Elanor, after she was prescribed an old and dangerous drug, Diane-35, also marketed under names like Brenda-35 and Juliet-35. This drug has never been approved for use in the USA and was actually banned in Europe in 2013 after too many women died from blood clots, and it was only reintroduced with tough restrictions. Yet it's routinely prescribed to Australian women without proper warnings, education or consideration of safer, modern alternatives. Since first talking publicly of our experience I've been deluged with horror stories of life-threatening or fatal blood clots by families from across Australia. I've also researched the issues and met with health regulatory authorities and professional bodies. I have no hesitation in saying there are women in Australia who needlessly die or are harmed by this drug.

In our case, in January we were staying with family friends in Kandy, Sri Lanka. I got back from an early morning walk and Elanor was lying on her bed and she said, 'Dad, my leg pain's worse and I think I have a deep vein thrombosis and need to go to a hospital.' I said, 'Darling, that's a bit dramatic for 9 am, have you had breakfast?' She said 'No Dad, look, my leg's swollen, I can't pull my foot up and the calf pain is worse.' Luckily she recognised the classic DVT symptoms as she works at a medical clinic and helps with ultrasounds. The first hospital we went to just wanted to ice it and bandage it as a sprain, so I commandeered a car to drive three hours to Colombo, where Elanor was diagnosed with a life-threatening DVT and hospitalised for a week.

We made it home a fortnight later and she's had a harrowing year of daily blood thinners, blood tests every few days, stockings, ultrasounds and medical appointments galore. The clot slowly shrank but stubbornly would not clear. After resigning herself to the advice that the residual clot may be with her for life she stopped the blood thinners six weeks ago, and thought she'd do one more scan for luck. Miraculously this last scan showed the clot appears to have cleared—although she still has swelling, intermittent pain and vein damage, potentially lifelong, and one hell of a beige leg stocking. She'll never be able to take oestrogen-based medication again, she struggles to get some types of insurance and any future pregnancy will be high risk.

So why did Elanor's DVT happen? The medical consensus is it happened because three factors combined. First, her doctor prescribed her Diane-35, which heightens the risk of blood clots in women. This drug is only registered in Australia by the TGA for two indications—idiopathic hirsutism or signs of androgyny, really where other drugs have failed. Yet unknown thousands of Australian women are prescribed it 'off-list' or 'off-label' because a side effect of this drug is it's an effective contraceptive even though it's not registered in Australia for this purpose.

The TGA wrote to me making clear that off-label prescriptions are not endorsed by the TGA. Yet everyone knows this drug is widely prescribed as a sexy-sounding first-choice contraceptive. Elanor's doctor wanted her to take a contraceptive pill to regulate her irregular periods, but she was never advised it was an off-label prescription, warned that the risk of blood clots on this old-style drug is 1½ to three times higher than more modern, safer alternatives, or educated about the signs to look out for. The risks are heightened in the first three months of taking it, like most medications. The second factor was that, after starting this drug, she took long-haul flights. Astoundingly, the same doctor did her overseas travel vaccinations, even though the drug's fine print says not to take it on long flights. Third, Elanor also had a fairly common genetic variation that increased the risk of blood clots. Around one in 20 Caucasian women have the Factor V Leiden gene, but there's no routine testing in Australia, even when women are prescribed old-fashioned, riskier drugs like Diane-35. The doctor prescribed Elanor this drug without knowing she had a fairly common genetic variation and then hopping on a plane almost killed her.

The important question now is: what needs to be done to reduce the risk to other Australian women of being hurt? I've had productive discussions through the year with the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the Pharmacy Guild, the Royal Australian College of GPs, the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, the National Prescribing Service, and law firms expert in medical negligence and regulation, and I plan to meet with medical insurers. It is clear to me that we need to improve Australia's overall pharmacovigilance regime, or, in plain English, our drug safety systems that minimise harm. Importantly, we need to overhaul systems in this country in relation to off-label prescribing, because the risks of adverse effects are heightened when a drug is prescribed for a purpose other than that for which it is approved by the TGA. The system should ensure that Australian pharmacists are always made aware when a prescription is off label and also if a drug is being prescribed to a patient for the first time. That way, the pharmacists can engage with patients to ensure greater awareness and acceptance of the risks and possible side effects, which is an extra and potentially life-saving check in the system—which some countries have, but we do not.

In relation to Diane-35, if this drug is to remain in Australia at all, then much tighter controls over it are needed. The reality is that, despite this drug not being approved as a contraceptive in Australia, doctors and pharmacists think of it as one. It's listed under 'contraceptives' in the pharmacy manuals and it's stored with them. Everyone I've spoken to has admitted privately that this drug is a problem. Two of the executives I met at one of the regulatory agencies told me in frustration that these pills are known as sleepover pills. I said, 'Why's that?' They said, 'They're named after a girl you had stay over as if they're your friend, but they are not.' A refreshingly direct statement came from my meeting with Dr Bastian Seidel, President of the Royal Australian College of GPs. He told me he doesn't think Diane-35 should be available in Australia anymore. He wisely observed that the real issue is that this is an old drug, but we don't delist legacy drugs in Australia, even when there are newer and safer alternatives. Drug companies can withstand or fight off the odd lawsuit and still make money. So a mechanism to delist or restrict such legacy drugs is a policy issue that governments should look at. But that won't happen quickly, so more immediate action is needed.

I'm pleased that, since I raised this issue, work is underway to improve education and awareness amongst doctors, pharmacists and consumers. In response to a letter from the TGA after my meeting, the National Prescribing Service is now working to raise awareness amongst practitioners of the risk of blood clots from drugs like Diane-35. The NPS is also scoping a consumer awareness campaign for social media to raise awareness of the risks and safer alternatives. This is important, because one of the issues driving the prescription of Diane-35 is the consumer pressure on doctors. My daughter saw this on social media chat groups, where some young women think this is a good pill because 'it makes your skin nice'. Well, there's not much use in having nice skin if you're dead from a blood clot! The Pharmacy Guild and the PSA have committed to updated professional education modules on women's health in light of Elanor's case.

Secondly, more research and data is needed to understand this problem. There's strong evidence that this drug is prescribed far too widely in Australia. Everyone knows it; everyone admits it. But there is no reliable way of knowing how widespread this danger is, because data isn't collected in Australia about off-label use if it's not on the PBS. This should change. The NPS are interrogating their data now to try and identify patterns in the proportion of prescriptions that are likely to be for contraception. But, without system changes, it's likely that only the drug companies know how big this problem is, and they have no incentive to tell.

Thirdly, there is a clear need for tougher restrictions and warnings, so I will write again to the TGA, requesting tighter restrictions through scheduling of this drug, either by requiring a formal authority for GPs to prescribe it, which should be available only after a Factor V Leiden blood test is performed and negatived; or, if this isn't possible, its availability should be restricted in future so that only certain specialists, such an endocrinologists, can prescribe it, and only after ruling out genetic blood disorders. To support this, blood testing for genetic risks such as Factor V Leiden should be available on the Medicare Benefits Schedule. I will also write to the Minister for Health asking him to encourage applications and quickly agree to any recommendations.

Product warnings are also important. In 2016, Australia's Advisory Committee on the Safety of Medicines conducted a full review of combined oral contraceptives in light of this drug being banned in Europe because it was killing women. It recommended the harmonisation of product information statements, amongst other things. Shamefully, the only pharmaceutical company that has refused to make the recommended changes is Bayer, which manufactures Diane-35. The TGA, however, has the power to require warnings on the packaging of drugs in Australia. I will call on the TGA to require a warning be added to Diane-35 and all generics that says in big bold letters, 'This drug is not approved as a contraceptive in Australia', which will help to influence consumer and prescriber behaviour.

Being stuck in the ICU in a foreign country was a traumatic experience for my daughter. The doctors and the medical staff in Sri Lanka were fantastic, but we did have to take RID into the ICU so she didn't get dengue fever from the mosquitoes. It certainly wasn't a comfortable experience, but she eventually made it home.

In conclusion, I dearly and sincerely hope that my daughter's experience, and the steps I've outlined, will reduce the risk of other Australian women suffering life-threatening blood clots. I thank all of the professional bodies that I mentioned—the TGA, the Royal Australian College of GPs, the National Prescribing Service and the pharmacists—and also my colleagues, the member for Macarthur, who's a practising paediatrician, and the member for Dobell, who's a pharmacist, for helping me undertake this research. Finally, I thank everyone involved who has spoken up about their family experiences. I hope we can do better.
Chisholm Electorate
Ms BANKS (Chisholm) (18:41): December is a time of reflection, and 2017 has been a magnificent year in Chisholm. I'm so pleased to recount the many successes of our wonderful community here.

Chisholm is an iconically multicultural community. Regardless of our cultural heritage or ethnicity, Australians across Chisholm are united by a shared belief in the important values of freedom, family and enterprise. The Chisholm community represents the best of liberalism, respecting and upholding our freedom to celebrate different cultures in this great country we call home. It's about upholding religious freedoms and the individual enterprise, which is so evident every day and always throughout the Chisholm community.

Every day in Chisholm, over a hundred different languages other than English are spoken in our community and families and friends regularly gather to celebrate their unique cultures and traditions. Throughout the year, I have been honoured to represent our Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull, at myriad cultural celebrations. I loved joining Chisholm's substantial Chinese and Taiwanese communities at the colourful and vibrant Box Hill Chinese New Year and Moon Festivals, the Telugu Association of Australia for their 25th anniversary celebrations, attending the 20th anniversary of the Taiwanese School of Melbourne, the welcome dinner for Chinese star Yang Liping and the Under Siege review cast, a celebration of the 106th year of the Republic of China Buddha's Light International Association of Victoria, Fo Guang Shan Melbourne's Buddha's Day and Multicultural Festival known as Vesak Day, the 33rd Annual Theofania—the Blessing of the Waters—the Oakleigh Glendi Festival, the Lonsdale Street Greek Festival and the Diwali celebrations, to name just a few. My sincere congratulations to community leaders who ensure that these important celebrations and traditions are passed down through generations of Australians of migrant and varied cultural heritage.

Our nation has been vastly enriched by faiths of every tradition, each contributing its own unique and special thread to the multicultural fabric of our society. Perhaps the greatest celebration of our culture and heritage is on Australia Day, where Chisholm residents and Australians nationally gather together and celebrate the myriad attributes which make our society so rich and so vibrant. On Australia Day, and at wonderful times throughout the year, I was thrilled to attend citizenship ceremonies run by the Whitehorse City Council and the City of Monash where hundreds of Chisholm residents proudly became citizens of Australia, the world's most successful multicultural nation. With diversity comes a richness and vibrancy that is something to be treasured and celebrated. Australia Day is a traditional day for all Australians, especially given that one of the things we subliminally celebrate is our freedom to enjoy our cultures, traditions and a merger of them.

By far the best part of my role as the member for Chisholm is the amazing people I meet every day who make a difference to our local and broader community. If I were asked to name one thing that makes me proud to be Australian it would be the volunteering spirit and the fact that Australians across the board always help those in need. The Chisholm community is strengthened and enriched by the many hardworking people who dedicate countless hours to our local sporting clubs, neighbourhood houses, social groups and other fantastic organisations. In June I held the inaugural annual Chisholm Volunteer Awards night, at which we had the honour of a very special guest, the Hon. Julie Bishop, who joined me in naming Mr Trevor Eddy as the 2017 Chisholm Volunteer of the Year and in giving many well-deserved awards to the volunteers. Having the Minister for Foreign Affairs take the time to attend and to give these awards with me is a testament to how truly appreciative the Turnbull government is of the thousands of Australians who contribute and volunteer their own time. Forty-two recipients and their friends and families all gathered at Crossway in Burwood in celebration of Chisholm's rich volunteer culture, and our foreign minister warmly welcomed them and gave them their prizes.

Throughout the year I have enjoyed visiting and being visited by a plethora of community groups, including the Box Hill Lions, U3A Box Hill, Rotary clubs from across Chisholm, Oakleigh-Carnegie RSL, Box Hill RSL, Clayton RSL, Neighbourhood Watch, Neighbourhood Houses and Centres, community information services, Eastern Volunteers, Burke & Beyond, Melbourne Eastern Residents Association, Alkira, Migrant Stitches and Crossway Lifecare. Our volunteers are the threads that hold together our communities, and I know I speak on behalf of all Chisholm residents when I sincerely thank all of those who dedicate countless hours to the betterment of our community.

Throughout the year, Chisholm's schools, universities and TAFE were abuzz with a love of learning and education. Throughout the year I had the pleasure and honour of attending many local schools to award school leadership badges and certificates. I've gone from honouring new school leaders at the commencement of the year to looking forward to attending graduation ceremonies in coming weeks. Some key school based events this year included hosting our foreign minister, Julie Bishop, at Avila College in Mount Waverley, presenting at the Presbyterian Ladies College Participating in Politics program and representing the Prime Minister at the Day for Daniel—Daniel Morcombe—at St Mary Magdalen's primary school in Chadstone, as well as visiting many other local primary and secondary schools. I also was very happy to welcome a number of Chisholm schools, including Mount Waverley Secondary College, Orchard Grove Primary School, Christ Our Holy Redeemer, Huntingtower School, Mount Waverley North Primary School, Mont Albert Primary School, Mount Scopus Memorial College and Ashwood School to our parliament when they visited Canberra. I was also thrilled to visit Box Hill Institute with the Minister for Employment, Michaelia Cash, to discuss how Box Hill TAFE is a fantastic provider of the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme.

Monash and Deakin universities continue to provide world-class tertiary education for students from Chisholm and beyond. This year I was pleased to visit fantastic research centres, such as the Monash University Food Innovation Centre, the Monash Health Translation Precinct and the new Monash University diabetes research laboratory, as well as to see the manifestation of integral research at Deakin's ALLPlay dance program. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull visited Monash University with me, and it was the first time a prime minister had visited Monash University, Australia's largest university, since 1989.

I'm proud to be part of the Turnbull government, as we have backed and supported many local clubs, including many clubs that have worked hard to ensure the active participation of young girls and women in sport. Providing equal opportunity for women to participate in sports often translates into their leadership attributes and experience in other spheres, such as business and community life. For future generations of women in leadership, leadership in sport translates to leadership and equality in business and the community, and it is integral to continuing the great Australian tradition of sport participation for future generations. Clubs such as the Box Hill Hawks, Surrey Park Junior Football Club, the Box Hill United Pythagoras Soccer Club and Waverley Hockey Club are actively looking forward to the future by including women's participation in sport, and I am proud to say that many Chisholm sporting clubs continue to expand and include girls at all levels.

I am pleased to announce that, also in round 3 of the Stronger Communities Program, Harlequin Rugby Club, Nunawading Basketball Association, Kerrimuir United Cricket Club, Nunawading City Soccer Club, Eastern Lions Soccer Club, Ashwood Sports Club, Mount Waverley City Soccer Club, North Box Hill Tennis Club and Box Hill United Pythagoras Soccer Club were all successful in their applications for grants, with a particular focus on backing girls in sport and providing appropriate infrastructure to best facilitate their participation.

On Australia Day and on the Queen's Birthday, some extremely worthwhile individuals who live and work in Chisholm were acknowledged as part of our nation's honours system. I acknowledged them at the time but wish to again highlight their integral contributions to our community. On Australia Day, Mrs Rosemary Brown, Mr Keith Irvine, Mr Alexander Hehr, Mr Bernard Millane, Professor the Hon. Nahum Mushin, Professor Evan Simpson, Professor Jane den Hollander, Mr Christopher Thorn and Mr Michael Wells were recognised for their invaluable work in our community. On the Queen's Birthday, Mr Paul Bonsak; and Mr Norman Fettell, known as Rex, were also recognised as wonderful Australian citizens who contribute to our society and live in Chisholm.

Representing the electorate of Chisholm is a great honour. As my speech tonight is testament to, our community is so rich and diverse. I'm amazed everyday by the many wonderful elements of our community and am so grateful to represent them in this place. I'm particularly proud to reflect on a fantastic year in Chisholm during this week in parliament, a week where members and senators have gathered to legislate for marriage equality. I was personally thrilled and over the moon when 61.6 per cent of Chisholm residents voted yes in support of the marriage bill, and I am proud to vote yes in this place as their representative. This year, 2017, has been an extremely busy and productive one, and I look forward to the year to come.
Airport Noise

Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (18:51): Recently, Airservices Australia changed the flight paths into Hobart Airport in a way that directly impacts rural communities in the south of my electorate. For the people on Forestier Peninsula, which is about 50 kilometres north of Port Arthur, the first they knew about this change was when they were woken up at 3 am by freight planes overhead, flying low on their descent. This isn't a nimby issue. The people of Dunalley, Murdunna, Bream Creek and other affected communities know that flight paths have to go somewhere. This is an issue of appalling consultation and of impacts that could have been avoided with a little more forethought and care by the authorities.

My home in Penna has had planes flying overhead for years on their way to the airport, but they're high overhead and hardly noticeable unless you're looking up. That is very different to what now faces people on the peninsula—very loud aircraft at all hours of the night and day, as there is no curfew in Hobart, and an impact that is only set to get worse as the airport gets busier and as it prepares to accept bigger jets, including from China.

The communities affected have not previously been under flight paths. They are quiet, rural communities that are recovering from the devastation of the 2013 bushfires, and they are developing agritourism ventures with wine, oysters and accommodation. Being under new, noisy flight paths is hardly what they bargained for, and they had no idea it was coming. If the new flight paths are necessary to improve safety, and that has been the claim from Airservices Australia, then so be it—except no evidence has been presented that these changes are necessary and, certainly, no evidence has been presented that safety on the former routes was ever an issue.

It has emerged through a lot of tortuous discussion that the so-called safety benefit of the new route is simply this: less communication is required between the tower and the pilot on approach. Airservices argue that this lessens the risk of human error. Essentially, on the new routes, once the plane gets into the formal and narrower flight-path route, it is essentially 'set and forget' from the tower's point of view. But no-one, as far as I have been able to discover, has ever argued that the old system was a potential risk—not the pilots association, not the air traffic controllers association, not the unions, not the airport. This seems to be about streamlining processes. That's a laudable goal, to streamline your processes and make them more efficient, but given the price to be paid by people on the peninsula, the people of my electorate, I do not think this change meets the cost-benefit test. And community consultation has been farcical. There were no ads in the newspaper, no community forums, no flyers and no liaison with me or the member for Franklin, or with Tasmanian senators of any party.

Like many authorities, Airservices Australia makes it difficult to speak to a real human being, and that's been a matter of considerable frustration to Dunalley residents like David Patman who were badly impacted by the changed routes and who simply wanted to express their concerns and get more information. David contacted me and together we managed to get through to a real person, and as a first step we strongly encouraged Airservices Australia to run a community forum in Dunalley, actually getting to the community and talking to people on the ground; listening to the community, explaining why the changes were necessary, taking on board their concerns and having a go at developing acceptable alternatives.

Meanwhile, David and the community kept the pressure on, with petitions, and contacted Minister Chester's office. The preference from the community and my preference is to ask for the old routes to be reinstated while the efficacy of new routes can be examined. But that has not occurred. We are pleased that Airservices finally agreed to a community forum, but I was very disappointed when I saw it was to be held at 11 am on 11 November. Some mad scrambling, after we explained the difficulty with such a time clashing with Remembrance Day services, resulted in the forum being reset to 11.15 am. Despite that awkward time and lack of notice, more than 70 locals from Dunalley and surrounds turned out. Instead of it being a public meeting, residents were carved off into small groups in private rooms to have the changes explained to them—the old divide-and-conquer rule. Despite the good faith on display from residents, it was clear that the exercise was what I feared it might become—a tick-a-box consultation: 'We've had the consultation; tick that box.'

Airservices did propose an alternative new route at that forum, and despite many concerns raised by residents about the impact of the suggested new route that's what Airservices came up with some weeks later, saying, 'Oh, well, we've consulted the community and here's the route.' Lo and behold, that's exactly what they've presented. Other alternatives that affected fewer residents were ignored, with no explanation given as to why they were not explored further. Airservices had simply made up their mind. It defies belief that with the vast tracts of unoccupied land and water on the southern approaches to Hobart Airport a more suitable path affecting fewer residents could not have been found. This new route may be convenient for Airservices Australia, but it will continue to have devastating impacts on residents and tourism businesses on the peninsula. It will also have significant and unknown opportunity costs. Can the area still transform itself post-bushfire as an agritourism centre? Will investors be interested in risking their money on boutique ventures when passenger and freight jets fly low overhead?

I have informed Airservices Australia of my deep disappointment with their handling of this issue, and I will continue to work with the community to press for an outcome that meets the needs of both a growing airport and the local community. The ball is now clearly in the court of transport minister Chester. He can choose to either stand up for regional communities or continue to sit on his hands while Airservices Australia run roughshod over the folk of my electorate. The Nationals like to put on the big hats and act like they're working in the interests of country people. Well, Minister Chester, here's your chance. Here's your chance to work in the interests of people in rural communities. Tell Airservices Australia to revert to the old flight paths and order a proper consultation process for the development of new routes, if they are required, which take into account the likely impacts on rural communities.

In the two minutes I have left, I'll talk about the NBN in Lachlan, in the Derwent Valley. There's a wireless tower there which NBN Co has agreed needs an upgrade. The town of Lachlan has 300 people in it and they're all connected to the wireless tower, and it's oversubscribed. Basically, more people are trying to use that tower than should be. At peak hour, it can get as slow as one or two megabits per second. That is essentially so slow that people like Luke Cashion, who contacted my office, cannot even run a speed test on it. Luke's organised a petition of the Lachlan community. In just a few days, he's organised 45 signatures. He is not the only one affected by this. Schoolkids home from school, people working from home and others simply cannot use the internet in the afternoons at peak time. That's not good enough. The NBN has agreed it's not good enough, and an upgrade is on its way. The NBN says, 'You can wait till the second half of 2018.' They are expecting residents of my electorate, the residents of Lachlan, to wait at least six months—probably more like 12 months—before they get around to upgrading the wireless tower at Lachlan. That's simply not good enough. Minister Fifield really should get involved. He is another minister who sits on his hands, waits for advice from his advisers and does nothing other than what he is told—an absolutely hopeless minister. Get that tower upgraded now. We know that, under the coalition, the NBN has become second rate. We know it's slow. We know it's not fit for purpose. At the very least, you can fix it for the people of Lachlan.
Agriculture

Mr BROAD (Mallee) (19:01): I haven't got lots of grievances; I've got lots of things to celebrate. At the moment, we are harvesting across the Wimmera Mallee. The harvest is a good time. It's a time when, frankly, people receive the benefits of their soil, water, sun and sweat; you combine those things together and produce food. There's something very noble about agricultural production. It's a pleasure to speak in front of you, Mr Deputy Speaker Coulton, because you know something of this.
An honourable member interjecting—

Mr BROAD: You might learn a little bit if you're quiet. Even though you might not have great grain prices, you'll get quite a lot of pleasure when you're sitting on a harvester receiving the rewards of all that hard work—
An honourable member interjecting—

Mr BROAD: I cannot understand the complete rudeness in this chamber when I'm talking about something that's not controversial. It shows the character of the people sitting on the other side, when they can't even listen when I'm simply talking about food. I am amazed by the character of this person, because I've always treated her very decently.

Can I talk about the harvest. People go out there and do a lot of hard work. When you see the bunkers when you're driving along, you look at them and think about what a blessed country we are and how blessed we are to have the people who are out there putting in that hard work. A lot of the sowing of the crops across the Wimmera Mallee is now done dry. Because of the seasons, and we don't get those big opening rains, people put those crops in, spending up to $300,000 or $400,000 of their own money sowing fertiliser and seed into dust. They are sowing in hope, and this year they're reaping the reward.

The government plays a key role in this. Whilst we've got to harvest the crops, we have to get the crops from the paddocks to our arterial roads. The federal government is putting $20 million a year into Roads to Recovery. Roads to Recovery was an initiative of John Anderson, a former Deputy Prime Minister of Australia. It was said that the best expenditure of money was to give it to the local councils so they could upgrade local roads. Of course, a B-double can weigh in excess of 60 tonnes. They have to be able to get down over those culverts, over those dirt roads, so they can get to our arterial roads. The federal government has put more money into those federal roads in the electorate of Mallee: the Calder Highway, the Western Highway and the Sturt Highway. I'm pleased to see the upgrading that's taking place there—upgrading that needs to happen. The challenge for us is that, when we think of roads, we tend to highlight those that have large traffic loads rather than those that roads that may not have the high traffic loads but are critical to our economy. If we produce something and can't get it to the market, then all Australians are the poorer for it. You may not have huge numbers of trucks like you have on a busy freeway in Melbourne, but the product that goes on those trucks is of economic benefit to Australia.

We've also invested in rail. Darren Chester, the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, was excited to announce $240 million to build the Murray Basin Rail Project. That is upgrading and standardising rail in my patch. Did you know that Mildura to Melbourne is the busiest freight rail link in Victoria? Now we'll be able to take trains with 24-hour turnaround, high-value horticulture and up to 150 shipping containers per train. Each of those shipping containers can have in excess of $80,000 worth of table grapes. I took Michael Sukkar, the assistant minister, to have a look at it last week, and he was amazed, frankly, at the amount of product coming out of our area, the prices they were getting and the confidence. Everywhere we went, they were talking about expansion.

That expansion has been able to be achieved only because of the free trade agreements with China, Japan and Korea that were signed by Andrew Robb. Those boxes are scanned, packed in containers and sold before they even leave Wakefield Transport, then sent down to the Port of Melbourne and shipped across to China, Korea or Japan. We haven't talked enough in this place about the one thing that has driven economic growth in our patch: those free trade agreements, opening up those markets.

There's no point having markets if you can't grow the stuff. The other thing that the federal government has done is invest in water infrastructure. Water is the lifeblood of agriculture, and it's something that our side of politics clearly understands and that side of politics doesn't. When Senator Wong was the water minister, she put through a policy which said that, if a farmer wanted to get out of farming and sell their bit of water, they had to pull up their water infrastructure, sell that water to the Commonwealth and not use that block for production for five years. It was diabolical. Essentially the government bailed out someone who wanted to leave, and put the cost of production, the cost of water, onto the person who wanted to stay, making them wear double the costs.

In contrast, we came in and put $103 million of federal money into upgrading irrigation infrastructure, granted tax deductibility status if you wanted to make irrigation upgrades on your own farm and also allowed for $20,000 instant tax write-offs. Fortunately, it is now five years since Senator Wong was the water minister, and those blocks are coming back into full production. They're getting the tresses and wires in, the vines are being planted, and the water infrastructure is being rebuilt. Senator Wong is the least popular politician to have ever walked the streets of Mildura, because we are still cleaning up the legacy of her mismanagement after five years. It shows the contrast: her vision was that the place was dead and dusted, and they were going to shut it down; our vision is, 'We're going to open markets, put common sense back into water policy and make the place boom.' Mr Deputy Speaker, you've had the great privilege of visiting the wonderful town of Mildura, and I think you can confirm just how much enthusiasm there is and that it is a booming place.

We have built 11 NBN towers around the outskirts of the town, which has been our doing, and that has put telecommunications there. We've also just recently upgraded the runway so that a customer from China can fly on a Chinese coded airline—incidentally, Virgin is now Chinese coded—directly to Melbourne and take the 737 to Mildura, Chinese coded all the way, have a look at the products they're going to buy, experience the community and place their order. Those products are then making their way to other parts of the world. It has been a real jigsaw, a piecing together to drive productivity, and it's been a result of the decisions we've made—decisions about roads to recovery, delivered by the National Party; decisions about rail, delivered by the National Party. It is the biggest investment in freight rail in Victoria's history, delivered by the National Party and the federal government under Darren Chester.

There's investment in roads. The federal government has put $20 million into the Western Highway and the Calder Highway. It has been the free trade agreements that have opened up those markets. It has been the investment in irrigation infrastructure, with $103 million as well as getting the economic settings right after that investment in irrigation infrastructure. And it has been the investment in runways and telecommunications.

The other thing that has been the sleeper—that probably isn't seen as an investment but is clearly an important part of government—is getting stability back in the water market. People talk about managing our water better. The one way you take away confidence is to say to the Australian people, the Australian irrigators, 'We're going to take away your water; you are managing it badly. We need to send it down to South Australia. We need to keep the river mouth open. You are to blame.' And someone says, 'I was going to put a centre pivot into my farm. I was going to put some new technology on my farm. I'm not going to do that now, because I may not have water.'

We have put stability back in the water market. The Deputy Speaker's son was a key person in that advisory role. It has incentivised people to say, 'There is a future for me. It is worth putting in new irrigation infrastructure. There is a future for our town. It is worth spending the money to put a centre pivot in.' It's about getting the policy settings right: free trade agreements, infrastructure and water policy. Those are the things that, when you piece it together, deliver a great country and wealth, and when we get that wealth we have the capacity to build the society we want. It all starts in regional Australia, and it all starts with good decisions by this government.
Lindsay Electorate

Ms HUSAR (Lindsay) (19:12): I have a lot of grievances on behalf of my constituents. Given the time of the year it is and that people are more festively focused than they are on things that aren't working, I decided to take a different approach to this speech. I am continually impressed by the strength of my community and the decent hardworking people I represent and get to call my neighbours. I can't say it enough but we do have the best people living in my electorate. I don't want to do this with hubris but I would like to go through some of our achievements, tinged with some of the things this government might like to do better.

This year in Lindsay, as with most electorates, we welcomed new citizens. But we now see that the citizenship application process has been delayed somewhat by the immigration and border protection minister, with his ridiculous policies around a level 6 English test, among other things. Our Lions Club has celebrated its 60th anniversary and I would like to acknowledge the club president, Steven Holley, and thank him for the club's continued support of our community. They are stepping into the void and filling things in our community and doing projects that ordinarily a government might handle.

In March, at my International Women's Day awards, we launched a shelter for women and children who are victims of domestic and family violence. That shelter is being looked after by a team of volunteers. It will be staffed by experts when we come to opening it. Of course, this is something where governments could intervene and not take away funding. It has been ripped out of that sector and put into normal bulk homelessness housing rather than specialist homelessness services for victims of domestic violence. We celebrated International Women's Day at our Penrith Women's Health Centre, and I'd like to make mention of the incredible work being done by everybody there. Ninety per cent of their work is in domestic violence. It would be great to see the government jump on board and provide certainty around funding. I'm not talking about the federal government, I'm talking about Stuart Ayres and the Liberals in New South Wales.

We opened a new water park for a community that sees 45 degrees in summer. It's a pretty phenomenal achievement, having that for our community. We've had a groundbreaking ceremony for a new retirement village. The private sector, of course, was called in to help look after our aged because there are no housing options for them. The Nepean Men's Shed has opened, and we have the biggest men's shed, per square metre, in the whole of the country—or at least we did back when we opened it. And I'd like to say thankyou to Tony Hudson, the secretary, for his dedication in getting it up and running.

And through the hard-fought campaign of most of my community we saw that our Nepean hospital finally got a boost to the amount of funding that it will receive; $550 million will be coming into that hospital. But, again, we should be getting about $1 billion, when you compare it with what other Sydney hospitals were given. And given that it won't meet our current demand, let alone our future demand, it is another short-sighted decision by the Liberals in New South Wales.

The fantastic students at Werrington County, Werrington Public, Cambridge Park and Cambridge Park High School, along with our deadly dancers, had a great performance earlier this year. And Grace Brinkley, the president of the Penrith seniors and pensioners club, has been really supportive of me and my work across the electorate this year. We opened a new school for a specific purpose over at Glenmore Park, and Fernhill has been operating for a year now, with Julie Raciborska at the helm leading that school.
