I was incredibly proud to attend their very first awards ceremony last week, before coming down here, and to see the joy on the students' faces. How far they've come this year is an incredible achievement, and congratulations to Julie on that.

I have been appointed as patron of the Nepean Family History Society, which has been a great joy to me. We have a volunteer group of people in our community who are adamant about researching all the family histories of every member of our community. NAIDOC Week was celebrated. We've run over eight mock parliament sessions in local schools, and the PCYC has overseen its upgrading and reopening of the club. Our Nepean Football Association registered 12,500 players, many of whom are just from my community. Western Sydney University successfully supported students in their learning but now, sadly, face a cut of $98 million, which is the highest cut of any university in New South Wales and the second-highest cut anywhere in this country.

If you were in an electorate like mine, in Western Sydney, with some of the pressures faced by ordinary families, you would see that cutting $98 million to that university is the dumbest decision ever made by almost any government. The M4 toll was reintroduced by the Liberals in New South Wales. They congratulate themselves on making commuters in my electorate pay another $2½ thousand per year just to get to and from work. At the same time, they actually managed to completely ruin the train timetable. Now about 15 minutes has been added, give or take, to the commuters' journeys. So, you can get on a train and take about an extra half an hour per day for your return trip, or you can get on the M4 and pay a toll—which was already paid for and which we removed, and then they put it back on. But it is not just for the term or life of that road being paid for; it'll go for about 40-something years. I think I'll potentially be at retirement age, provided that this government doesn't keep boosting that.

People in my community have been interested in what's been happening, and we've been able to offer a number of forums over the last year. We could have had even more going on if we'd had a Labor government, because a Labor government would have actually invested in my community, not continued to rip the guts out of it. And who knows when the election might be called in 2018? Hopefully it'll be sooner rather than later—not that I look forward to facing another election campaign, although this time I'll do it on two legs and not one. But we would have seen investment with a Labor government in Western Sydney, and in Lindsay in particular.

Many, many forums have been attended by the wonderful members of our community who are interested in what's happening in aged care. Julie Collins came out to visit us. We launched the Lindsay Awards—the first time we've actually recognised and supported the work of the phenomenal women in my community and what they've been up to. We had an education forum with Tanya Plibersek and Jihad Dib, the member for Lakemba, and an urgent meeting on the education cuts that saw $17 billion cut out of our primary school and secondary schools. Chris Bowen came out to meet with our local businesses, and I got to welcome 80 new babies to our community, which is probably one of the biggest highlights of my year so far. The Australian Jobs Taskforce visited and heard from our community about the things that are lacking. At the same time we had Doug Cameron visit, for the Western Sydney Apprenticeship and Traineeship Expo. The Medicare task force, headed by Sharon Claydon and Mike Freelander, was attended. We had about 25 doctors from our own community come along and give evidence about the appalling conditions they are stuck working in, which is an absolute blight on this government. There was also the housing forum, with Senator Doug Cameron, to discuss the issues around affordable housing, and climate change and energy, with Mark Butler and Adam Searle.

While we are talking about climate change and energy, people in my community faced 20 days of over-33-degree heat in February of this year. We reach phenomenal temperatures on an extended basis, so energy prices are incredibly important—not only that but getting something done about climate change and renewable energy is very much on our minds, especially with the new solar energy provider that has just opened in our electorate. We'll be one of the only ones to be able to sell the new Tesla batteries that are going to be available for homeowners.

Recently we had an NBN forum which someone renamed the 'No blooming internet forum'. That was the pet name for the forum because people cannot actually connect to the NBN or, when they do, it is incredibly slow. Chris Bowen and Amanda Rishworth came out to celebrate our veterans. We also had a childcare roundtable to talk about the accessibility issues for early childhood education. Those accessibility issues go to people with children with a disability who can't afford reliable early childhood education or after-school and out-of-hours care. That is not meeting the needs of vulnerable families.

The people of Lindsay care about our community and their investment in our local community. They want to see some action. They don't want to see it stagnate. All they see is an out-of-touch Prime Minister. They want to see more local jobs and not 83 per cent of our community having to commute over an hour every single day in one direction just to get to their place of employment. They hear a lot about the '30-minute city' and being able to get to jobs and education, but then they see a government that does the opposite, which is cut money for a local university. I have been out at the train stations, at the mobile offices, at 'Coffee with a Pollie' and at the forums to let people know that I'm there. We've received and addressed more than 1,200 representations for our local community.

While I'm here, I would like to thank my hardworking staff—Jane Shelton, Lara Greenhill, Catherine Sargent, Angela Hadchiti and Phoebe Fuller—for the incredible work they have done in the Lindsay electorate office this year and will continue to do into the new year. I look forward to the election next year, when we can, hopefully, get a Labor government and deliver for the people of Lindsay.
Energy
Perth Stadium
Food Labelling

Mr IRONS (Swan) (19:22): I will take this brief opportunity to note one grievance, but, like my colleague who was here previously, the member for Mallee, I will be talking about some positive aspects of things that have happened within the community as well. I just wanted to remind my electorate about the issue with power prices in Western Australia. At the last state election, which the Liberal Party lost to the Labor Party, one of the issues that was raised heavily was the sale of Western Power. The Labor Party vehemently opposed it because they said it would raise power prices. The Labor Party won the election, and so, obviously, Western Power wasn't sold. But one of the first acts of the Labor Party was to put up power prices by 10.9 per cent, which flew in the face of their campaign that said, 'Don't sell Western Power because prices will go up.' But it's the old story with Labor: don't listen to what they say; watch what they actually do. That is what Western Australians and all the people of my electorate now have to suffer—an extra 10.9 per cent in power prices under the state Labor government. Mark McGowan, who opposed the sale, introduced that as one of his first acts in government.

The other thing I wanted to remind my electorate is that we've got the stadium opening soon. It, again, was developed by the Liberal Party. At the launch in 2010, the now state Treasurer Ben Wyatt was there, turning the sod with Colin Barnett and all happy about it. But in 2013, at the state election, Mark McGowan and Ben Wyatt, the local Victoria Park member, opposed the stadium. They said, 'If we get elected, we will not build this stadium.' What's happening now is that they're part of the state government and they are having their photos taken everywhere, launching the opening of the stadium. That is going to happen next week. They want to take all the credit for something they actually opposed back in 2013 and said they would not build if they got elected. Again, don't listen to what Labor say; watch what actually they do.

Mr Deputy Speaker Coulton, the rest of my speech will be of deep interest to you. I recently had the Assistant Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources visit my electorate. One of the things we did was launch a new office. It was a combination of the Perth NRM and the WA Farmers Federation. They have joined together to occupy an office in my electorate on the Great Eastern Highway. I look forward to the symbiotic relationship they will have working together. It was a very positive morning with a lot of people excited about the prospect of those two not only sharing an office but working together. Then Minister Hartsuyker and I attended the local IGA store in Preston Street and we did some promotion of the country of origin labelling, which I'm sure you might have done in your own electorate as well, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was great to do that and meet people and present them with information about the country of origin labelling.

With that country of origin labelling, the reforms commenced on 1 July 2016 with a two-year transition period to allow businesses time to comply with the new arrangements. The transition period ends on 30 June 2018. Under the reforms, the labels for most food that is grown, produced or made in Australia must include a logo—a kangaroo and a triangle symbol—as well as a bar chart and, where appropriate, a text statement to show the proportion of Australian ingredients. More information on the Country of Origin labelling reforms is provided on websites, and a range of COOL examples are also provided on some of the websites, which I will name at the end of my speech.

The instore demonstration provided consumers with information about the new COOL reforms and showed them the range of examples what the new labels look like and where they can find more information. We handed out some notepads, which had the details on the back, to some of the people who were shopping in the store. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, after extensive consultation with industry and consumers, the new reforms came into effect on 1 July, and these reforms provide consumers with clearer and more consistent information about how much of their food is actually Australian. As I said, the reforms: include a two-year transition period; replace the current requirements in the Australia and New Zealand Food Standards Code with a new mandatory information statement created under Australian Consumer Law; close a loophole that allowed some food to be labelled as 'packaged in' without indicating where it was grown or made; simplify claims by clarifying what 'substantial transformation' means; and remove the complex 50 per cent local production cost test to reduce regulatory burden across all industry.

At the moment, food that can currently be sold without an origin label will continue to not need a label. This includes food sold for immediate consumption or made and sold on the premises in places such as restaurants, cafes and bakeries, and also at the farm gate, which would hold a deep interest for you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

To support industry, the Department of Industry, Innovation and Science has developed a range of business support initiatives for these reforms, and they are available at foodlabels.industry.gov.au and business.gov.au/foodlabels. In addition, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has developed a suite of educational material for businesses at accc.gov.au/business/advertising-promoting-your-business/country-of-origin-claims. I welcome these reforms. The country of origin label is important, not only for our farmers but for consumers to know where their food and products are actually coming from.

In short, I thank Minister Hartsuyker for coming to my seat of Swan and enlightening the consumers with that information, as well as assisting with the opening of the new NRM-Western Australian Farmers Federation office.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Coulton ): There being no further grievances, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order for the next day of sitting.
